college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Law and legal issues are deeply integrated in most facets of business. Our course introduces some of the core legal issues that managers commonly face. I have asked legal practitioners for input to guide the Core areas. In addition, there will be extra material available for those who want to explore more topics. To help structure the course, we will be using a textbook that takes a management, rather than a purely legal, approach to different topics. In addition, to emphasize the RSM mission of being a force for change, we will be emphasizing the ethical areas where law is less clear and managers must navigate challenges and face uncertainty.

The focus of the course will be on US and UK legal language and the common law system. This motivation is very practical: the vast majority of international contracts draw on these systems, English is most often the preferred language in international business dealings, and we need a common platform as a starting point to illustrate issues and develop awareness. In reality, some grounding basics really help managers identify legal issue, communicate with legal teams, and trouble shoot a range of business-and-legal issues (Bagley, 2008). We will highlight some major differences in systems and contracts (and other legal documents) throughout the topics.

The ultimate goal of the course is for you to begin to develop an awareness of legal issues and to add legal insights to your business acumen. A deeper understanding of legal issues in business can create advantages among managers and firms, leading to value creation and protection (Bagely, 2008). We know that legally astute managers with the ability to use legal language and communicate with a basic understanding of law are more effective negotiators, have stronger contracts, and are even able access more affordable financing. In addition, these managers are able to better manage alternatives to courts and legal conflict (Pinkham & Peng, 2017).
  Leerdoelen
  1. Identify legal issues relevant to the firm and international issue.
  2. Apply basic, English legal terminology in international contracts and other documents.
  3. Follow legal reasoning and how lawyers and fact finders may evaluate a case.
  4. Develop a response to ethical and legal issues that may arise in international business and the multinational enterprise.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

This course consists of two important domains in psychology as they are relevant for business:

  • human decision-making
  • behaviour in teams

The course is taught as a mixture of interactive lectures, in-class exercises, and workshops that allow students to explore key topics in organizational behaviour, e.g., essential concepts in judgement and decision-making, bias in decision-making, strengths and pitfalls in persuasion, cooperation and conflict, cognition and information processing, and diversity in teams.

Regarding human decision-making we will discuss the assumption of rational decision-making versus biases by normatively irrelevant factors. We will show that other people influence our choices. The course will give you an understanding of the psychology of judgment and decision-making, with the ultimate, overarching goal of making you a better decision-maker. How can you overcome your biases and improve your choices? How can you make sure that you and your collaborators finish your project on time? These are important challenges for anyone’s career, independent of your specific professional goals. Understanding these questions will help you improve your (personal) insights in the process of decision-making.

Regarding behaviour in teams, the course addresses the challenges associated with coordinating the efforts and expertise of different team members who are working towards a common team goal. Furthermore, we will explore different strategies that help teams overcome challenges and pitfalls in team collaboration. Special attention is given to diversity in teams and the impact it can have on team dynamics.

Complementing the lectures, the course includes a number of practical exercises and discussions of real-life cases that will allow you to engage with the course content on a more experiential basis and highlight how the theoretical concepts and models relate to management practice.

This course is worth 4 EC.

Leerdoelen By the end of the course, students will:
  1. Discuss essential concepts in judgment and decision-making
  2. Use insights from psychology to persuade and resist persuasion
  3. Understand essential concepts in team dynamics
  4. Apply theoretical concepts on real-world situations

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Where theoretical knowledge serves as the foundation of your education as a manager, the ability to effectively and insightfully apply this knowledge is the key to success in most management jobs. Developing the ability to apply and translate theoretical knowledge to real world situations in which taking decisions and implementing them is central is of crucial importance for future managers and is the key aim of this course. Just like pilots learn to fly in a flight simulator, you and your team will learn through a simulation to run a company for the next 10 years (10 decision periods)! You start with a portfolio of existing brands and your ultimate goal is to maximize your stock price index 10 years later, through value creation for your consumers. During these 10 years, you and your team decide which segment(s) to focus on and with which brand(s); how to target each segment and which price to charge. You are responsible for the effective management of a portfolio of brands:  you can reposition existing brands, redevelop them or discontinue them, but you can also introduce and launch new brands and products. Moreover, you get the opportunity to conquer a completely new market and to create value through sustainable choices. Apart from having an in-depth understanding of the strategic aspects of marketing, it is of vital importance that you learn to interpret market research studies accurately. On top of that, just as in real life, your company doesn’t operate in a vacuum but in a competitive environment. Your team competes with five other firms (five other teams) for consumers’ attention within the ‘markstrat world’. Effective and timely anticipation of your competitors’ (re)actions is of crucial importance for successful management of your firm.
In this course, you will deepen your knowledge and understanding of marketing, strategy, finance, product development and leadership. Through active engagement in the simulation, you will develop the skills to translate this knowledge into actionable decisions.
  Leerdoelen Learning goals
After finishing this course:
  • The student will have an in-depth understanding of concepts, theories and instruments important to marketing, and have the skills to apply these effectively in a way that creates value to the consumer. Therewith, the student obtains an understanding of how marketing can be a ‘force for positive change’ to the consumer.
  • The student will have the knowledge and skills to appreciate and interpret different market research studies.
  • The student has insights in optimal resource allocation strategies and in quantifying returns on marketing investment within a competitive landscape
  • The student has the skills to anticipate forces and changes in the market and responses from key stakeholders.
  • The student has developed leadership skills within the team to together with the skills to match external changes (in the market) with internal changes (in team structure and responsibilities)
  • The student has obtained an understanding of different biases that interfere with optimal decision making as a manager, and has the skills to fight these biases (e.g., overconfidence; attentional blindness)

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
In today’s volatile, uncertain, complex and ambiguous (VUCA) business environment the challenges of strategy development and implementation are greater than ever before. This course teaches you a new approach to strategic decision making to motivate and mobilize stakeholders to achieve the business’s overarching goals, such as making a profit and delivering on people- and planet-related objectives.
The course consists of 6 sessions. Articles, book chapters, case studies and (short) videos help you prepare for the sessions. In the sessions you work on real-world cases and exchange insights. Your skills are tested by means of an individual exam based on a case. Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
After completing this course, students should be able to:
1.    Analyze present strategic problems and opportunities at the business level
2.    Create, evaluate and make decisions about strategic options for addressing these present issues
3.    Create an implementation plan for a business strategy
4.    Appraise foresighted strategic problems and opportunities at the business level
5.    Create, evaluate and make decisions about strategic options for anticipating these foresighted issues

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['ACM Bul', 'AFM Hof', 'dr. CLP Pennings', 'dr. J van Dalen', 'MH van den Doel']
text:
Inhoud

Concreet komen de volgende onderwerpen aan bod:

  • Algemene methodologische onderwerpen met betrekking tot causale inferentie, hypothesevorming, conceptuele kaders en meetschalen
  • Correlatie en multivariate regressieanalyse
  • Classificatiemethoden met behulp van logistische regressie, beslissingsboom, random forests, gradient boosting en naive Bayes
  • Clustering door middel van k-means en hiërarchische methoden
  • Beoordeling van de prestaties van geschatte modellen, van zowel regressiemodellen als classificatie technieken
  • Verklarende versus voorspellende modellen
  • Elementaire tekstmining en sentiment analyse, met behulp van tweets, nieuwsartikelen en mogelijk andere online bronnen

 

Leerdoelen
Het vak business analytics gaat over statistische en machine learning methoden en technieken en de toepassing van deze technieken in onderzoek. Het vak heeft een theoretisch deel, dat de achtergrond van deze methoden en technieken uiteen zet, en een toegepast deel, dat de vaardigheden opbouwt om ze in onderzoek toe te passen. De hoorcolleges gaan in op de theoretische achtergrond van meet- en analysetechnieken en geven voorbeelden van het ontwikkelen van enquêtes en de toepassing van technieken op data. De wekelijkse opdrachten trainen de programmeervaardigheden om de technieken in de praktijk toe te kunnen passen. De groepsopdrachten omvatten deze technieken in een relatief ongestructureerde taak over het onderwerp deeleconomie. Het vak draagt ​​bij aan onafhankelijke evaluatie en toepassing van kwantitatief empirisch onderzoek.

course_title: Capita Selecta Europese BTW en andere indirecte belastingen
college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud
Het betreft een verdiepend vak, dat met name Europeesrechtelijk van aard is. Naast een aantal principes uit de Europese verdragen en richtlijnen komt de jurisprudentie over de BTW van het Hof van Justitie aan de orde, alsmede de ontwikkelingen op het terrein van de BTW en andere indirecte belastingen in Europa. Het vak vormt een aanvulling op het vak Omzetbelasting dat in de bachelorfase wordt aangeboden.
Voor elk college dienen de studenten twee stellingen te formuleren en vooraf in te leveren, om over de collegestof een mening te vormen. Iedere stelling moet gemotiveerd worden met een tekst van circa 1 A4 (450 woorden).
Tijdens de colleges gaan de docenten nader in op de stellingen en de daarover gevormde meningen van de studenten. Het gemiddelde van de stellingen vormt 50 procent van het eindcijfer. Het schriftelijk tentamen vormt de overige 50 procent van het eindcijfer.
Leerdoelen
  • Beter en verdiepend inzicht verwerven in het Europese BTW-systeem in het bijzonder met betrekking tot specifieke en verdiepende deelonderwerpen.
  • Het kritisch vermogen ontwikkelen om – zeker bij de deelproblemen – bij grensoverschrijdende transacties zelfstandig de fiscale belemmeringen op te sporen en op te lossen.
  • De vaardigheid ontwikkelen om dwarsverbanden te leggen en zelf met een deelonderwerp aan de slag te gaan, bijvoorbeeld voor het schrijven van een masterscriptie.

course_title: Capita Selecta internationaal en Europees belastingrecht
college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud Het kenmerkende karakter van het vak is dat het een verdiepend vak is. Dat betekent dat een aantal onderdelen die ook in de algemene vakken internationaal belastingrecht en Europees belastingrecht zijn behandeld, hier op een diepgaander niveau aan de orde komen. Daarnaast wordt aandacht besteed aan een aantal specifieke deelterreinen van het internationaal en Europees belastingrecht.

Thema's die de revue passeren zijn onder andere:
  • Arbeidsinkomsten
  • Staatssteun
  • Dividendstructuren
  • Bijzondere fiscale regimes
  • Responsible taxation
  • Internationale aspecten van schenk- en erfbelasting
Voor elk college dienen de studenten twee stellingen te formuleren en daarover hun mening te vormen. Elke stelling moet gemotiveerd worden met een tekst van circa 300 woorden. Het gemiddelde van de stellingen vormt 50 procent van het eindcijfer. Het schriftelijk tentamen vormt de overige 50 procent van het eindcijfer. Leerdoelen
  • Beter en verdiepend inzicht verwerven in het internationale en Europese belastingrecht, in het bijzonder met betrekking tot specifieke en verdiepende deelonderwerpen.
  • Het kritisch vermogen ontwikkelen om – zeker bij de deelproblemen – bij grensoverschrijdende transacties zelfstandig de fiscale belemmeringen op te sporen en op te lossen.
  • De vaardigheid ontwikkelen om dwarsverbanden te leggen en zelf met een deelonderwerp aan de slag te gaan, bijvoorbeeld voor het schrijven van een masterscriptie.

college: Erasmus School of Law
text:
Inhoud Tijdens het vak Capita Aansprakelijkheidsrecht vergaart u kennis van diverse onderwerpen[1] op het gebied van het aansprakelijkheidsrecht. Bij dit vak wordt voornamelijk gebruik gemaakt van gastdocenten; specialisten op het gebied van de te behandelen onderwerpen. Naast de colleges, waarin een actieve werkvorm centraal staat, zijn er ook masterclasses. Tijdens deze masterclasses bezoekt u steeds een organisatie (advocatuur/verzekeringsbranche) waar een van de onderwerpen uit het vak wordt uitgediept waardoor direct de uitwerking daarvan in de praktijk zichtbaar is.
 
[1] De belangrijkste capita zijn structuur van het aansprakelijkheidsrecht, verjarings- en vervaltermijnen, beroepsaansprakelijkheid, werkgeversaansprakelijkheid, verkeersaansprakelijkheid, productaansprakelijkheid en overheidsaansprakelijkheid. Leerdoelen
  • U kunt de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het civiele aansprakelijkheidsrecht analyseren en uiteen zetten.
  • U kunt de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het civiele aansprakelijkheidsrecht toepassen op een feitencomplex.
  • U kunt ten aanzien van de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het civiele aansprakelijkheidsrecht een kritische houding aannemen, een standpunt innemen en in discussie gaan.
  • U kunt op het gebied van de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het civiele aansprakelijkheidsrecht ontwikkelingen signaleren, analyseren en (actualiteiten) bijhouden.
  • U kunt verschillende leerstukken op het terrein van het civiele aansprakelijkheidsrecht analyseren, vergelijken, verbanden leggen en bepalen welke op een casus toegepast kunnen worden.
  • U kunt de opgedane kennis van de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het aansprakelijkheidsrecht omzetten in praktische kennis en u kunt daarbij de trends en ontwikkelingen signaleren.

course_title: Capita selecta fiscaal recht: Transfer pricing
college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['B Broen', 'dr. MJ Luth - Morgan', 'SDA van Rooijen, MSc LLM']
text:
Inhoud De Capita Selecta Fiscaal Recht valt uiteen in verschillende specialisaties. Hieronder volgt een korte beschrijving van de Capita Selecta Transfer Pricing:
 
Tijdens de colleges staat het Transfer Pricing vakgebied centraal. Zo zullen wij tijdens de colleges uitgebreid stil staan bij de internationaalrechtelijke aspecten van Transfer Pricing, alsmede de Nederlandse implementatie van de Transfer Pricing regels, inclusief bijbehorende jurisprudentie. De Transfer Pricing discipline is volop in beweging. Tijdens de colleges zullen daarom ook de recente ontwikkelingen op het terrein van de Transfer Pricing aan bod komen.
 
Voor iedere capita geldt:
De hoorcolleges worden verzorgd door gastdocenten uit het bedrijfsleven, de belastingadviespraktijk, de rechterlijke macht, de belastingdienst, ministeries, etc.
Voor de Capita Selecta geldt dat de deelnemers maximaal tweemaal afwezig mogen zijn. Tevens wordt actieve participatie verlangd. Iedere student moet in tweetallen een verhandeling schrijven en de essentie ervan presenteren gedurende maximaal 15 minuten. Daarnaast wordt elke student eenmaal aangewezen om een verslag van een van de bijeenkomsten te maken. Voor een nadere omschrijving wordt verwezen naar de brochures die per Capita Selecta beschikbaar zijn op Canvas. Leerdoelen Zie de algemene eindtermen van de opleiding

text:

Aan de orde komen de staatkundige vernieuwing van het Koninkrijk der Nederlanden, de directe en indirecte belastingen, formeel belastingrecht, belastingrechtspraak in het Caribisch gebied, tax incentives (tax holiday, e-zone), internationale aspecten (verdragen, BRN, BRK, verhouding met EU), misbruik van offshore vennootschappen (Panama leaks, 'Ultimate Beneficial Owner'), tax haven en ethiek. Daarnaast wordt een uitstap gemaakt naar het fiscale stelsel van Suriname.

course_title: Capita selecta: Van eenmanszaak tot internationaal concern
college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['dr. MJ Luth - Morgan', 'mr. A Benhammou', 'mr. I Roozen', 'mr.dr. EW Ros']
text:
Inhoud De Capita Selecta Fiscaal Recht valt uiteen in vijf specialisaties. Hieronder een korte beschrijving van de capita selecta Van eenmanszaak tot internationaal concern:
 
De cyclus van 16 colleges wordt begonnen met verschillende aspecten die van belang zijn voor familievennootschappen behandeld. Daarbij gaat het om zowel civielrechtelijke als fiscaalrechtelijke aspecten. Onderwerpen die daarbij aan de orde komen zijn: bedrijfsopvolging in de inkomstenbelasting en vennootschapsbelasting, de bedrijfsopvolgingsfaciliteit voor de schenk- en erfbelasting, het creëren van holdingstructuren, horizontaal toezicht en tax assurance, ethiek en renteaftrekbeperkingen.
Met betrekking tot het internationale deel van deze capita zullen de volgende onderwerpen behandeld worden: Inbound en outbound investeringen, het begrip vaste inrichting, winstallocatie, ethiek, doorstromers, immigratie en emigratie aanmerkelijkbelanghouder, transfer pricing, misbruik van belastingverdragen, fiscale aspecten van grensoverschrijdende werknemers en hybride entiteiten, belastingconcurrentie, staatssteun, BEPS/ATAD en belastingheffing in de digitale economie. De focus bij deze onderwerpen ligt op het internationale concern.
 
Voor iedere capita geldt:
De hoorcolleges worden verzorgd door gastdocenten uit het bedrijfsleven, de belastingadviespraktijk, de rechterlijke macht, de belastingdienst, ministeries, etc.
Voor de Capita Selecta geldt dat de deelnemers maximaal tweemaal afwezig mogen zijn. Tevens wordt actieve participatie verlangd. Iedere student moet in tweetallen een verhandeling schrijven en de essentie ervan presenteren gedurende maximaal 15 minuten. Daarnaast wordt elke student eenmaal aangewezen om een verslag van een van de bijeenkomsten te maken. Voor nadere informatie wordt verwezen naar de brochures die voor deze Capita Selecta beschikbaar is op canvas. Leerdoelen Zie de algemene eindtermen van de opleiding

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['mr. M de Vries', 'mr.drs. JK Stam', 'prof.mr. N van Tiggele - van der Velde']
text:
Inhoud Het verzekeringsrecht staat niet op zichzelf. Er wordt altijd "iets" verzekerd en dat "iets" kan met vele juridische deelgebieden verweven zijn. Verzekering vervult in onze moderne samenleving met alle daaraan verbonden kansen en risico's ook een onmisbare rol in het veilig stellen van de sociale zekerheid voor het individu. Dat maakt het verzekeringsrecht tot een boeiend onderdeel van het recht. Het betekent ook dat kennis van het verzekeringsrecht niet alleen onmisbaar is voor juristen die in de verzekeringsbranche zelf werkzaam (willen) zijn of bijvoorbeeld in de advocatuur de belangen van verzekeraars vertegenwoordigen. In feite loopt iedereen die in een juridische functie (rechterlijke macht, bedrijfsleven, overheid) werkzaam is, de kans met verzekeringsrechtelijke vraagstukken te worden geconfronteerd; zoals dat ook privé het geval is. Ook maken meerdere Masterclasses deel uit van het vak. In het kader van deze Masterclasses zullen meerdere advocatenkantoren, verzekeraars en/of assurantiemakelaars worden bezocht. Tijdens deze Masterclasses staan onderwerpen centraal die in het onderwijs aan de orde zijn. Leerdoelen
  • De student kan de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het verzekeringsrecht analyseren en uiteen zetten.
  • De student kan de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het verzekeringsrecht toepassen op een feitencomplex.
  • De student kan ten aanzien van de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het verzekeringsrecht een kritische houding aannemen, een standpunt innemen en in discussie gaan.
  • De student kan op het gebied van de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het verzekeringsrecht ontwikkelingen signaleren, analyseren en (actualiteiten) bijhouden.
  • De student kan verschillende leerstukken op het terrein van het verzekeringsrecht analyseren, vergelijken, verbanden leggen en bepalen welke op een casus toegepast kunnen worden.
  • De student kan de opgedane kennis van de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het verzekeringsrecht omzetten in praktische kennis en kan daarbij de trends en ontwikkelingen signaleren.

college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
text:
Inhoud This course is part of cluster 4. The Politics of Wealth: Inequality, Capitalism, Exploitation

This course covers state-of-the-art debates in political philosophy, including the debate on permissible commodification and the nature of markets, on contemporary justifications of property, on the feminist and the three-dimensional theory of power, on justice as fairness and its approach to economic inequality, on neo-republicanism, and on contemporary theories of exploitation. Leerdoelen

To provide students with advanced knowledge of contemporary political philosophy. By the end of the course, students should have an understanding of state-of-the-art debates in political philosophy, the ability to think well about them, and the ability to assess relevant philosophical theories in terms of their cogency and explanatory scope.


Attendance at lectures and seminars is mandatory.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Inequality is considered by many as one of the great issues of our time. All too often, current rising inequality – both domestically and internationally – is connected to global free marked capitalism, leading critics to propose a fundamental reform of the economic model. As it turns out, things are not that straigthforward.
 
In this series of lectures and seminars the interrelationship between capitalism and (in)equality is the central topic. Neither of them exist in a vacuum and can only be defined historically. Debates on how to, the one hand, earn wealth and how to distribute it on the other, go back as far as Antiquity. Essentially, this is a debate about the tensions between liberty and equality How did historians, economists and sociologists (DelaCourt, Locke, Tocqueville, Smith, Mill, Marx, Weber) debate these issues in the past? And what does history itself teaches us? Is there indeed a correlation between commerce and inequality? Where do the roots of modern inequalities in wealth lie, and what has been the role of states, institutions, culture or colonialism?
  Leerdoelen
Students learn how economic inequality is labelled by sociologists, historians and economist in the past as well as in contemporary times. They recognize various research methods, assumptions and theories of capitalism. They learn to reflect on academic debates on the origin of capitalism and inequality. At the end of the course the students are able to write an independent written essay and reflect in an academic way on the origins of capitalism and inequality in a particular well defined historical case.

college: Erasmus School of Economics

text:
Inhoud In the year 2020/2021 Erasmus School of Economics introduces a new course called ‘Career Skills’. This course aims to foster a better connection between the study at ESE and the labour market. After you have completed your first Bachelor year you will experience that you need to make choices rapidly that define the rest of your (study) career; minor, major, electives, going abroad, a side job or other extracurricular activities… It is the wish of ESE to stimulate every student to make informed choices regarding their studies and for the start of their career. In addition, we want to support students in developing the skills necessary to succeed in a professional environment. That way, you will be well prepared to enter working life!

On the Career Skills Hub on Canvas you can find the latest information about the activities pertaining to Career Skills, as well as general rules, FAQ, etcetera.
You are required to register yourself for the actual activities (courses) during the ordinary registration periods before each block.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud Improve your Dutch language proficiency;

Important note
This course is part of the Career Skills programme. Be aware that you can only do one Career Skills course in each block, and you can do a maximum of two courses per academic year.

Improve your Dutch language proficiency
Do you want to learn Dutch for your future career? Are you going to do an internship at a Dutch company? Or would you simply like to make yourself understood in the Netherlands? This Dutch language course will help you get there!
The Dutch language course will be offered for beginners (block 4) and for non-beginners (block 3).
Since there will be only one non-beginners group with limited places, participation in the intake does not guarantee a place in the course.
The Dutch language course for non-beginners will help you to improve your knowledge of the Dutch language and culture based on everyday situations. The course consists of seven weekly sessions of 2 hours each.
The Dutch language course for beginners is offered in block 4. This course is only for those who have no knowledge of the Dutch language.
During the Dutch language course for beginners you will learn the basics of the Dutch language, with emphasis on reading, speaking, listening and writing skills in an everyday context. The course consists of seven weekly sessions of 2 hours each.

This course consists of seven online meetings (via Zoom) of two hours. Next to this the self-study and preparation time amount to circa 14 hours. Leerdoelen Learning goals
  1. gain a first understanding of basic Dutch grammar.
  2. build a vocabulary of Dutch language.
  3. ask basic, day to day, questions in Dutch.
  4. understand simple answers in Dutch.
Belangrijk om te weten Entry requirements:

You can register on SIN-Online, via Channel: Career Skills Hub (FEB63011 – 20).

Only accessible to non-native Dutch speakers.

To participate in this course in block 3 (the non-beginners group), it is a requirement to have obtained a positive course advice based on the intake performed by Language and Training Centre.


Resit policy:

After having obtained a 'fail', you lose one of your two opportunities to do a Career Skills course in the academic year.

You can redo the course at a next occasion, when you will need to do the full course again. Extra This course is part of the Career Skills programme. Be aware that you can only do one Career Skills course in each block, and you can do a maximum of two courses per academic year.

Bachelor-3 students
The courses in the Career Skills programme are also open to students who need one additional credit to complete their Bachelor programme. If you are a Bachelor-3 student, registration for the courses and tutorials groups takes place by sending an email to careerskills@ese.eur.nl .

Bachelor-2 student receive priority in registration for limited places, hence there is chance that you cannot be placed.

Bachelor-3 students can only do one course from the Career Skills programme.

course_title: Career Skills, English for Business Purposes
college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

Important note 1

This course is part of the Career Skills programme. Be aware that you can only do one Career Skills course in each block, and you can do a maximum of two courses per academic year.

Important note 2

Before the start of the course you are required to submit, via Canvas, a motivation letter why you want to participate.

Course content

Business English: Writing and Presenting
Effective business communication in English opens doors. Excellent communication skills in English are crucial for achieving international ambitions.
In this course you will work on your Business English writing skills, for example by writing polite, concise and correct business emails. You will also get the opportunity to practise your presentations skills in English by giving a persuasive and informative business presentation.
You will learn more about conventions in Business English in this course. You will brush up your English grammar and you will be able to improve and expand your English vocabulary.
By receiving individual feedback from your lecturer – who is an experienced language professional – you will be able to develop your business communication skills. You will also learn a great deal from working closely together with your fellow students.

This course consists of seven online meetings (via Zoom) of two hours. Next to this the self-study and preparation time amount to circa 14 hours. Leerdoelen Learning goals
  1. write a coherent and well structured English business text.
  2. write correct English on sentence level, including grammar, style and vocabulary.
  3. develop an efficient writing process
  4. give a business presentation in English
Belangrijk om te weten Entry requirements:

You can register on SIN-Online, via Channel: Career Skills Hub (FEB63011 – 20).

Before the start of the course, you are required to submit, via Canvas, a motivation letter why you want to participate.


Resit policy:

After having obtained a 'fail', you lose one of your two opportunities to do a Career Skills course in the academic year.

You can redo the course at a next occasion, when you will need to do the full course again. Extra This course is part of the Career Skills programme. Be aware that you can only do one Career Skills course in each block, and you can do a maximum of two courses per academic year.

Bachelor-3 students
The courses in the Career Skills programme are also open to students who need one additional credit to complete their Bachelor programme. If you are a Bachelor-3 student, registration for the courses and tutorials groups takes place by sending an email to careerskills@ese.eur.nl .

Bachelor-2 student receive priority in registration for limited places, hence there is chance that you cannot be placed.

Bachelor-3 students can only do one course from the Career Skills programme.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
lecturers: ['dr. M Szymanowski', 'IG den Hartog', 'LT Brakefield', 'NS Stunnenberg']
text:
Inhoud

Important note

This course is part of the Career Skills programme. Be aware that you can only do one Career Skills course in each block, and you can do a maximum of two Career Skills courses per academic year.

The aim of Your Future Career is to prepare students at an early stage in their studies for their career.
When you care about what you do, you will enjoy your work more, create greater impact, and be more successful. However, it can be difficult to identify what your passion is, where your competencies and skills will be useful, and which professional environment and culture are the best match for you. Therefore, the Career Skills programme offers you a course to put you in the driver's seat of your career, and to support you in identifying your first career step after graduation and preparing for it. 
The online modules of Your Future Career will help you make crucial steps towards the most suitable internship or job for you. To pass the course you need to gain 50 points by a set deadline. You can decide yourself if you want to reflect on your interests and motivations, develop knowledge of the job market, functions, organisations and industries, or receive peer feedback on your application materials.
 
This course will run from the start of block 4 till the end of block 5. You cannot start halfway the course.

 
       Leerdoelen Learning objectives
Orientation
  • Assess own individual professional profile in larger community
  • Show pro-activity in regard to career preparation

Explore yourself and the job market
  • Analyse your strengths and weaknesses, personality, values and skills
  • Identify different career paths in the job market
  • Identify career preparation gaps and create action points to fill the gaps
  • Understand the recruitment and application process in different industries

Develop and learn to communicate your personal brand
  • Assess how your future career can be a force for positive change
  • Create tailored job application documents
  • Demonstrate written and verbal communication skills needed in the job application process
Belangrijk om te weten Assessment is on a pass/fail basis (there is no grading in the Career Skills courses).

Resit policy:
After having obtained a 'fail', you may do a resit by gaining points for tasks you had not performed yet. More details will follow. Extra This course is part of the Career Skills programme. Be aware that you can only do one Career Skills course in each block, and you can do a maximum of two courses per academic year.

Bachelor-3 students
The courses in the Career Skills programme are also open to students who need one additional credit to complete their Bachelor programme. If you are a Bachelor-3 student, registration for the courses and tutorials groups takes place by sending an email to careerskills@ese.eur.nl .

Bachelor-2 student receive priority in registration for limited places, hence there is chance that you cannot be placed.

Bachelor-3 students can only do one course from the Career Skills programme.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud Belangrijke noot
Deze cursus is deel van het Career Skills programma. Let erop dat er slechts één Career Skills vak per blok kan worden gedaan, en dat er een maximum van twee Career Skills vakken per academisch jaar geldt.

Omschrijving
Onderstaande leerdoelen zijn onderdeel van de training:
- Het ontwikkelen van een efficiënt schrijfproces
- Het schrijven van een coherente en goed gestructureerde zakelijke Nederlandse tekst;
- Het schrijven van correct Nederlands op zinsniveau, op het gebied van grammatica, stijl en vocabulaire;
- Verslaglegging en rapporteren.

Om jezelf de zakelijke schrijfvaardigheid eigen te maken ga je aan de hand van een combinatie van theorie en verschillende praktische opdrachten zowel individueel als in groepsverband met de leerdoelen aan de slag. Hierbij krijg je zowel feedback van elkaar als van de docent.
Daarnaast krijgen je ook algemene tips, richtlijnen en schrijfadviezen gericht op het zakelijk schrijven.
Dit vak bestaat uit zeven online bijeenkomsten van twee uur (via Zoom). Daarnaast moet je rekenen op ongeveer 14 uur zelfstudie en voorbereiding. Leerdoelen
  1. foutloos Nederlands te schrijven.
  2. een coherente en goed gestructureerde zakelijke tekst te schrijven.
  3. leestekens in zakelijke tekst correct toe te passen.
  4. eisen aan een zakelijke tekst te kennen
Belangrijk om te weten Entry requirements:

You can register on SIN-Online, via Channel: Career Skills Hub (FEB63011 – 20).

Alleen toegankelijk voor studenten voor wie Nederlands de moedertaal is of die het Nederlands op minimaal C2 niveau (CEFR) beheersen.


Resit policy:

Bij een ‘onvoldoende’ resultaat verlies je een van de twee mogelijkheden in het academisch jaar om een Career Skills vak te doen. 

Je kunt het vak bij een volgende gelegenheid weer doen. Het vak dient in zijn geheel overgedaan te worden.
     Extra Deze cursus is deel van het Career Skills programma. Let erop dat er slechts een Career Skills vak per blok kan worden gedaan, en dat er een maximum van twee Career Skills vakken per academisch jaar geldt.

Bachelor-3 studenten
De vakken in het Career Skills programma zijn ook toegankelijk voor Bachelor-3 studenten die nog een extra credit nodig hebben om hun Bachelor-programma af te ronden. Als je een Bachelor-3 student bent, vindt aanmelding voor de vakken en practica plaats door een email te sturen naar careerskills@ese.eur.nl .

Bachelor-2 studenten krijgen voorrang bij de inschrijving voor beperkte plekken. Daarom bestaat de kans dat er geen beschikbaarheid meer is voor jou.

Bachelor-3 studenten kunnen slechts eenmaal een vak binnen het Career Skills programma doen.

college: Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud
Instructor: 
dr. Xi Chen (EUR)
 
This course aims to provide you with conceptual understandings and a selection of tools to help you learn about managerial insights from data. These understandings and tools come from the rapidly developing science of causal inference and experimentation. On the conceptual level, it covers basic questions like what is causality, and what is causal identification? It also presents a formal system for expressing and understanding causal relationships, with perspectives and tools synergized from multiple disciplines, including statistics (Robin causal model or the potential outcome framework), computer science (Pearlian causal model or causal graph) and econometrics (e.g., Heckman's marginal treatment effects, and the decision theoretical view on experimentation). Finally, it also provides an overview of the techniques used to measure these causal relationships, ranging from traditional techniques such as Fisher's exact p-value to recent developments such as causal mediation analysis and causal machine learning.

One major distinction of this course is that it focuses on how to address managerial and policy problems with the understandings and tools from causal inference. With this practical purpose, we will focus on synergies and intersections between different perspectives, and think about how to integrate insights from different perspectives to form our own understanding.
Leerdoelen By the end of the course students will be able to:
  • Explain the ideas and concepts of causal identification.
  • Describe different perspectives and models in causal inference.
  • Implement a selection of tools of causal inference in the course.
  • Interpret the results of causal models for managers and policy makers in written reports.
  • Form a learning schema for multi-disciplinary topics such as causal inference.

college: Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus MC Academie
Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. K Kavusan', 'dr. MG Baaij', 'dr. P Darnihamedani', 'dr. S Liu']
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description

In addition to formulating a competitive strategy that leverages a firm`s competencies, it is also important to update the strategy in response to developments that change the dynamics of competition. The fast pace of innovation requires firms to constantly upgrade their product and service offerings to remain competitive and be ambidextrous: firms should not only focus on exploiting their existing capabilities, but also on developing new and complementary competencies. Two important skills to strategically change a business is to deploy existing competencies in innovative ways, and to locate and benefit from external knowledge that will facilitate new innovations. This course allows students to acquire relevant knowledge and skills about navigating an increasingly complex innovation landscape and to practice it through case discussions and group exercises. Throughout the course there will be a healthy mix of theory and its application in real-life situations.

The course consists of theory and skills sessions. In theory sessions, we will focus on theories that can form the basis for strategic change. We will discuss both theories and their application on real-life situations. In skills sessions we will focus on developing the skills that enable the formation and execution of innovative strategies. In addition to individual study, you will form teams to work on a team project in which you will apply the theories and skills you learned in the course to a real-life case.  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives

After finishing this course students will be able to:
-    Formulate action plans to revise strategies in response to developments that change the dynamics of competition;
-    Develop ideas to revise a company’s business model to leverage the core competencies of the firm in innovative ways;
-    Appraise the value of external knowledge for innovation and identify appropriate sources for valuable external knowledge;
-    Distinguish between exploration and exploitation and evaluate the role of each in enhancing competitiveness through innovation;
-    Define a firm`s innovation ecosystem and describe the role of complementary external parties in developing new strategies to maintain competitive advantage;
-    Analyze: (a) developments that change the dynamics of competition; and (b) ideas to leverage the core competencies of the firm in innovative ways;
-    Create, evaluate and make decisions about options for new strategies and business models to: (a) respond to changing dynamics of competition; and (b) leverage core competencies.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. F Grommé', 'prof.dr. CL ter Hoeven', 'prof.dr. F Koster']
text:
Inhoud

Digital technologies, such as data analytics, sensors and algorithms, shape organisations and organisational processes – but how digital technologies are applied also is an outcome of organisational politics, cultures and identities. This course focusses on developing the analytical skills needed to understand the role of digitalisation in changing organisations, labour relations and professional practices - ànd vice versa. These analytical skills are relevant to take an informed standpoint on current policy issues such as how to manage the disruptive effects of platforms on the labour market, or how to make sure that automation does not introduce discriminatory algorithms in the provision of public services.

Each week we will review a contemporary debate regarding organisational change and changing modes of organising. Examples of these debates are the relations between digitalisation and the privatisation of public infrastructures, or the opportunities of digitalisation for civil society organisations and collective action. We will focus on key questions regarding the relations between digitalisation and organisational dynamics in three empirical domains: the economic domain; the public sector and civil society organisations; and research and higher education.

Students are invited to compare and contrast relevant theories and empirical insights from organisational sociology, public administration, digital sociology and science and technology studies. We end the course by applying our insights to the question of how to imagine and accomplish alternative organisational forms, for instance, cooperative platforms and citizen co-production.

Leerdoelen
  1. Reflect and engage critically with popular narratives about organisational dynamics and technological change.
  2. Knowledge and insights into cross-disciplinary theoretical approaches and concepts regarding the relations between digitalisation, organisations and organising.
  3. Be able to connect contemporary debates on digitalisation with insights from the recent history of information technologies.
  4. Be able to take a scientific standpoint on previous and future digital organisational transformations and their social and political implications, and be able to present this standpoint.
  5. Be able to reflect on methodological challenges arising from emerging research agendas on digitalisation, and be able to contribute ideas on how to meet these challenges.

college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
Language and Training Centre (LTC)
text:
Inhoud

In de cursus Chinees beginners 2 leer je Mandarijn Chinees, de officiële Chinese taal die gesproken wordt in grote delen van China, Taiwan, Singapore en in veel andere delen van Azië.

Deze cursus bestaat uit tien wekelijkse bijeenkomsten van 2,5 uur. Het afsluitende examen vindt na afloop van de cursus plaats op een vooraf vastgestelde datum (zie onderstaande planning). Aan het einde van de cursus is de stof van één cursusniveau behandeld.

Wat leer je tijdens de cursus Chinees beginners 2?

Deze cursus is een vervolg op de cursus Chinees beginners 1. Tijdens deze cursus bouw je verder op de eerder geleerde onderwerpen van de Chinese taal, waarbij de nadruk ligt op de vaardigheden lezen, luisteren, schrijven en spreken in een alledaagse context. Onderwerpen die aan bod komen zijn bijvoorbeeld:

  • de weg wijzen;
  • boodschappen doen en uit eten gaan;
  • grammatica;
  • vocabulaire;
  • de Chinese cultuur.
Leerdoelen Aan het einde van de cursus ben je in staat om naast bovengenoemde punten, ongeveer 200 nieuwe woorden in Pinyin te schrijven en ken je 20 nieuwe Chinese basiskarakters. Daarnaast beschik je over een bescheiden woordenschat, waarmee je eenvoudige en samengestelde zinnen leert formuleren waarmee je in veelvoorkomende en alledaagse situaties kunt communiceren. Het eindniveau van de cursus is beginners 2, vergelijkbaar met het A1.2 niveau van het Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR) en level 1 volgens de Hanyu Shuiping Kaoshi (HSK). Belangrijk om te weten
  • Het Language & Training Centre organiseert driemaal per jaar cursussen Chinees (oktober-december/januari-maart/april-juni).
  • Deze cursus is toegankelijk voor cursisten met een academische achtergrond (hbo/wo).
  • De steuntaal van deze cursus is Engels. In de lessen wordt echter zoveel mogelijk Chinees gesproken.
  • Het cursusmateriaal kost ± € 45,- en is niet bij de cursusprijs inbegrepen. In de bevestigingsbrief die je ontvangt als de cursus doorgaat, informeren we je over de details.
  • Van de deelnemers wordt verwacht dat zij naast de wekelijkse contacturen ongeveer drie uur per week aan zelfstudie besteden.
  • De groepen zijn klein: minimaal 12 en maximaal 14 deelnemers. Bij minder dan 12 inschrijvingen behoudt het LTC het recht om de cursus te annuleren.
  • Aanwezigheid bij de lessen is niet verplicht, wel raadzaam. Tijdens de laatste les vindt er een mondelinge toets en een luistertoets plaats. Om voor de cursus te kunnen slagen, dien je dan aanwezig te zijn.
  • De cursus wordt afgesloten met een schriftelijk examen. Met dyslexie kun je extra tijd krijgen voor dit examen. Vergeet niet om je dyslexieverklaring met je verzoek naar ltc@eur.nl te sturen.
  • Je ontvangt een certificaat als je de cursus afsluit met een 5,5 of hoger.
  • Lees ook onze voorwaarden.

college: Erasmus MC Academie
Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Contents, course description

Over the past few decades, scholars from multiple disciplines (psychology, economics, organizational behaviour and marketing) have gained deeper insight into how consumers make choices, including the non-economic features of the choice environment that can influence people’s choices (e.g., default decisions, displayed font). Many of these insights have challenged the traditional assumption that people make choices primarily in a rational, self-interested manner. These research programs have provided novel insight into how people deviate from “optimal” choices and the consequences of these “sub-optimal” choices.

Because these decision strategies and mindsets often lead to choices that have harmful consequences for business, society and consumer welfare, it is important that students as future business leaders a) understand the basic principles of consumer decision making and b) have the tools to implement strategies that change consumer choice in the desired manner (dubbed nudging). Doing so will help them in numerous ways, including (but not limited to): a) making them a better decision maker in your personal and professional life, b) improving their ability to attract and retain satisfied customers and c) ensuring that their business runs smoothly. 

Although there may be some overlap with contents typically seen in marketing courses on communication and advertising, Choice Architecture course provides a substantially different approach to understanding and changing consumer choice. Specifically, the current course will draw primarily from behavioural economics research, will be geared towards making sustainable choices at the individual, business, and societal levels, and will be aimed at developing choice-intervention strategies that can be implemented in a wide variety of contexts: one-on-one negotiations, team organization, risk management, policy design, among others, as well as more classic communication arenas such as social marketing.
Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives

1)    Recognize core tenants of normative and descriptive models of choice
2)    Recognize core tenants of dual-process theories of cognition
3)    Be able to differentiate between different types of heuristics
4)    Be able to differentiate between different types of systematic biases
5)    Analyse novel decision contexts to figure out what aspects of the decision context lead to peoples’ current choices.
6)    Design interventions to influence choices
7)    Appraise the efficacy of the intervention
8)    Evaluate the monetary and psychological costs of the intervention
9)    Debate whether the intervention is ethical or not.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud An industry, a media and an art, cinema is mostly enjoyed as a form of entertainment. Studying movies, unlike literature or painting, is often seen as a waste of time and an anomaly in higher education. Yet, the power of cinema to convince, to move audiences, and to provide influential stories should be carefully studied. This course will use several movies to understand their social significance, and how societies have replaced ancient mythologies with modern images.
 
Note: The maximum number of participants is 60. This course has mandatory lectures. Leerdoelen Using a combination of case studies and film history, Cinema and Society intends to help students appreciate cinema and its effects on societies. Movies from different eras and societies will be used to provide students with a better understanding of cinema.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Each week in “Cinemas in Context”, a different movie will be analyzed to understand its roots, context, place in pop culture, and future in high culture. Focus will be on movies able to create their own universe, hence the subtitle “Deep universes”. Using a combination of students’ research, lecturing and tutoring, the seminar aims to contribute to a better understanding of cinema from an academic and artistic point of view. At the end of the seminar, students will be able to understand several movies’ universes provided in the curriculum, along with some they will choose themselves.
 
Note: The minimum number of participants is 6, the maximum number is 25
 
  Leerdoelen "Cinemas in Context: Deep Universes" intends to contribute to the understanding of film studies by exposing students to in-depth research in cinema as an art and an expression of culture.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Contents, course description
With the Circular Economy elective, you are taking the next step in sustainability strategies.

Where most sustainability strategies today still focus on reducing a company’s negative footprint, in this course we will also look at making a pósitive footprint.
Academically, this can be referred to as ‘regenerative sustainable development’. For business it means: instead of adding a burden to doing business as usual, we’re implementing a positive agenda to company strategies, business partnerships and customer relationships.
 
An exiting and existing example is paint that cleans the air (produced by AkzoNobel), and during this course, we will look at several other examples in the market today and discuss concepts for the future. We will look into the business benefits ánd obstacles of implementing these alternative project and/or company strategies.
 
Would you prefer to make a great business out of contributing to society and the environment, rather than just postponing the damage a company has on the environment or people? Then you are welcome to step into the Triple Top Line paradigm; the core of our theories and practice.

You are happily invited to step forward with a daring proposal for your roadmap assignment, fiery debates in the lectures and bold ideas during the exercises.
Leerdoelen
Learning objectives
After following this elective you can:
  • Work with the Triple Top Line. You will not only learn and discuss the theoretic fundaments, but also actively practice it.
  • Implement the Triple Top Line in a company and/or project with a TTL ambitions text, TTL goals, transitional goals and a (strategic) roadmap.
  • You will go through this in exercises and work out an example in your individual assignment.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Course description (In a nutshell)

Emerging digital technologies, such as artificial intelligence (AI) and data analytics, cloud computing, internet-of-things (IoT), and the next generation mobile infrastructure, bring both disruption and opportunities to industries, business ecosystems, and firms. These technologies will create opportunities for circular business models, e.g. to do business within the ecological and planetary boundaries. Instead of the ‘take, make, and dispose’ attitude of the traditional and linear business, circular business will create value with recycling, refurbishing, reuse, and maintenance processes. Both the circular and digital transformation will influence customer relationships, redefine products and services, change the operations and value chain processes, enable new ways of collaboration in business ecosystems, and will shift the information frontier further, with fresh, fast, and more reliable information, and with new ways of business information management. Next generation business will develop both the circular and digital capabilities in a holistic configuration of people, processes, and technologies.
  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives

The first goal of the course is to provide students with a better understanding of how circular and digital business will create greater value and the differences between linear and circular, and analog and digital. Different circular processes, with recycling, refurbishing, reuse, and maintenance will be explored with a special attention to the data and information needs, and the potential of the emerging digital technologies.

The second goal of the course is for students to learn how to design and evaluate circular and digital business models in such a way that three dimensions will improve, e.g. people (customers, employees), profit (both financial and non-financial), and the planet (natural resources). Examples in floriculture, energy, manufacturing, retail, trade and transport will be used.

At the end of this course students will be able to:
•  Understand and explain the importance of circular and digital business capabilities for business and society success.
•  Analyze and design different circular and digital business models and identify strengths, weaknesses, and potential performance levels.  
•  Understand and apply the knowledge in real-life business cases.
