Institute for Housing and Urban Development Studies (IHS)
lecturers: ['dr. J Fransen', 'dr. MMJ van Eerd', 'EPAM Keunen', 'FE Raftery']
text:
Inhoud The course is focused on three main topics related to migration. Before each topic, participants have time to prepare by reading literature about the topic. Each of the topics will be introduced by a lecture and is followed by a workshop in which participants work on collecting information, analysing and discussing about this topic applied to a specific case study. They will present a synthesis of their case study to the other groups in the second week. The topics of the course are:
  1. Migration dynamics
  • Migration flows, patterns, trends globally
  • Migration drivers & restraints
  • Legal framework
  1. The city’s perspective
  • Departure cities
  • Host cities
  • Transit cities / Refugee camps
  1. The migrant’s perspective
  • Belonging, inclusion & segregation
  • Towards a new, rights-based legal framework
  • Cities of Welcome
The case studies on which these topics will be applied are:
  • Aleppuzha, India
  • Rotterdam, The Netherlands
  • Kampala, Uganda

Each of these case studies represents a context in which migration is (re)defining the city, where understanding the role of migration is critical. On the other hand, the reasons for migration, the context, the challenges related and the responses to migration are very different in each case. By diving deeper into a single case, participants will gain knowledge and understanding about the complexity of the situation, while also being able to grasp the differences with the other cases through the case presentations.
  Leerdoelen After the module, participants should be able to:
  • Describe current migration dynamics, at a global, regional and local level;
  • Critically reflect on implications of migration on sustainable & inclusive urban development;
  • Assess different governance responses and their relevance in a specific context; and
  • Argue and debate a position statement (debating skills)

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Course Overview
This module deals with intellectual property (IP). It introduces students to the various forms of IP and then focuses on patents, as acquiring patent protection is the most expensive form of IP protection. A patent is often a substantial investment for start-ups and small companies.
 
In this master elective, RSM students work together with technical students from the University of Delft. Their aim is to develop a business plan for a sustainable invention. For many students, this is the first time they have had to consider the IP implications of an actual product or process. This module combines IP theory with practice. It raises awareness of IP issues and is immediately relevant for students regarding the invention they are working on.
 
Course Information
  • This course is linked to the TU Delft course Clean Tech Business Study (MOT9515) ) offered by Delft Centre for Entrepreneurship. More details on this course will be published on:
    https://www.cleantechchallenge.nl
  • No previous knowledge is required for this course. However, students are recommended to read the overview of IP basics provided on Canvas before the lectures.
  • Topics:
    • An overview of all the different forms of IP – patent, copyright, design rights, trademarks and secrecy;
    • A review of patent law basics to assess the patentability of an invention and how patent claims work and are interpreted;
    • A review of 10 classic IP mistakes commonly made by entrepreneurs.
  • The workload consists of 2 lectures of 3 hours each, reading the designated articles and producing a group assignment.
  • Course structure:  2 lectures of 3 hours each. Delft and RSM students may also consult with the lecturer on IP matters that arise in the course of their business plan.
  • Attendance at the lectures is compulsory. The lectures combine theory and several practical exercises.
  • There is a group assignment based on a case. This assignment must be uploaded before the end of the RSM block 3.
 
Leerdoelen
More details on this course will be published on:
https://www.cleantechchallenge.nl/


Learning Goals
·         To identify all forms of IP that might be relevant to their invention.
·         To be aware of and understand the legal issues that can arise when seeking to protect an own invention or when using the IP of others.
·         To have a basic understanding of patent law, thereby knowing when patenting is an option and when not.
·         To recognize and avoid the typical and common mistakes entrepreneurs make with respect to IP.
​

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud
Instructors: Prof. S.J.G. van Wijnbergen (UvA), Prof. F. van der Ploeg (Oxford Un, UvA) and Prof. C. Fischer (VU)

Short subject description:
This course focuses on climate change: one of the greatest challenges of our time. What can the science of economics teach us about its causes and potential solutions? What are the costs and benefits of
climate change? Its impact on poverty? Should we tax carbon, cap-and-trade emission rights, or subsidize solar and wind power? Does the answer depend on how we value the future? Why/when should we discount the distant future less than the proximate future? What is the impact of risk and true uncertainty (ambiguity) on the discount rate? Can a trade off between growth and the environment be avoided, if so with what sort policies? Does trade harm the environment? Will our industry move abroad if we take a leading role and 'go it alone'? Can well intended climate policies actually accelerate global warming? What are good second-best climate policies? How to deal with climate tipping points?

Course contents:
  • Lecture I: Introduction: Energy Policy, Climate Change and Economic Growth; evidence on drivers of global warming and the effects of global warming on the economy (Rick and Sweder)
  • Lecture 2: Economics of Discounting (Sweder)
  • Lecture 3: Growth, Scarce Resources and Directed Technical Change (Sweder)
  • Lecture 4: Trade, Pollution Havens, and Carbon Leakage (TBD; carbon taxes, trade and border tax adjustments; Rick/Sweder)
  • Lecture 5: “Distributional aspects of climate policy;Climate Change, poverty and inequality (Rick/Sweder)
  • Lecture 6: Green Paradoxes (Rick)
  • Lecture 7: Dealing with Climate Catastrophes (Rick)
Leerdoelen After having completed this course, you will know the answers to the above questions, or at least you will be able to have an informed opinion; and you will be able to enter into the economic policy debate well informed.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Content, course description

Climate change is one of today’s most pressing issues, receiving international attention from political leaders, corporations, the media, advocacy groups, and the general public. In the future, it is likely to become even more pressing as the effects of climate change intensify resource competition, natural disasters, disease vectors, water and food scarcity, and refugee migration.

According to Sir Nicholas Stern, former chief economist of the World Bank, the impact of climate change is likely to change the international business environment dramatically. However, the business relevance of climate change is insufficiently understood by future decision makers in international management and society.
We believe that tomorrow’s business leaders should be educated on the key elements of climate change – the science, the evolving policy, and role of business. They can become an essential part of the solution, but only if equipped with a sound understanding of the challenges at hand and the processes by which new policies are constructed.

The Climate Change Strategy course and its Model United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) form an innovative educational approach to closing this knowledge gap. Our goal is to broaden students' understanding of climate change, climate policy, and their impacts on the future of business.
The course modules deal with the core issues of climate change and include a wide range of effective didactic tools and exercises. Students are given a deeper understanding of the background and consequences of climate change for business, and of corporate responses to it. Special emphasis is laid on international and national regulatory frameworks, and on emerging resource challenges and market opportunities. Furthermore the course will provide students with an opportunity to develop a broad set of personal skills such as negotiation, forming strategy, research, public speaking and debating.

The 2021 edition of the course will be simultaneously offered at eight leading CEMS universities and culminates in a two-day UNFCCC simulation event at one of the business schools. Students will be using the 2015 Paris Agreement created at COP21 and be simulating the upcoming COP27. Negotiations will seek to enhance the current Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) of countries and work out details of how the new mechanisms and funds will function. The big challenge is how to improve the current commitments to be in line with the universally agreed target of limiting global temperature rise to ‘well-below 2 degrees’.

Students will negotiate on issues such as mitigation of greenhouse gases (new voluntary targets, financing and compliance), adaptation to climate change (financing, climate change refugees, technology transfer), and market mechanisms (sustainable development mechanism, REDD+, aviation and shipping).
Students should attend and actively participate in the classes. Students are expected to engage in class discussions, ask questions of speakers, and demonstrate involvement with group exercises.

Links:

Promotional video of the course:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gXGvLvaq0Tc
Example blog of the Role Play in 2020, written by the fictitious media team: https://climategazette.wordpress.com/
UN Principles of Responsible Management Education (PRME) LEADERS+20 Competition Top 10 Placing for the course:
http://prme-leaders20.au.dk/
Media articles relating to the 2018 Climate change role-play (Model UNFCCC):
https://www.forbes.com/sites/rogertrapp/2018/05/22/future-leaders-gain-a-better-understanding-of-climate-change-2/#18e153f5477a
https://www.rsm.nl/about-rsm/ Leerdoelen Learning Objectives

At the end of this module the participant is able to:
• Understand the negotiation process under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC).
• Explain the roles and interests of the private sector, government and civil society in tackling climate change.
• Evaluate business strategies for climate change.
• Formulate a negotiation strategy for climate change negotiations.
• Apply negotiation skills in an international negotiations setting.

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud The ability to communicate effectively is very important for many professional practitioners. Professional communication differs from normal communication in a number of ways, for example by using professional interviews. Professional interviews have a clear purpose and how the interview is led and carried out should be geared towards achieving that goal. Good problem clarification, for example, is a condition of a good professional therapy or advice session. Furthermore, the client can expect that a professional takes the greatest care in dealing with his or her personal problems, which can be very sensitive issues. A number of basic communication skills and a good basic attitude are needed in order to achieve this goal. So, the aim of this course is to improve the knowledge and skills required for effective communication. Theory and research on communication is reviewed and basic attitudes and basic interviewing skills are practised in role-plays. Note. This course is not about the clinical interview as a tool for diagnosing clients. Leerdoelen The Clinical Communication Skills course will:
  • Help you gain insight into the processes in counselling a person with a request for help.
  • Help you gain insight into and knowledge of the Van der Molen, Lang, Trower & Look (2014) interview model and how to use this model
  • Increase your knowledge and understanding of the concrete skills needed to help a person with a problem
  • Increase your knowledge and understanding of the adequate use of these interviewing skills
  • Deepen your knowledge in cultural differences that exist between (counsellors and) clients in perceptions of mental illnesses and help you gain insight into the multicultural counseling competencies needed to help clients from different cultures.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['dr. ir. D. van Klaveren', 'E.M. Krijkamp, MSc', 'N. van Leeuwen', 'prof. dr. H.F. Lingsma', 'prof. dr. M.G.M. Hunink']

college: Erasmus University College
lecturers: ['dr. I Schabram - Viethen', 'M Vaughan - Waalwijk, MSc']
text:
Inhoud The WHO (Geneva, 2001) estimated that 450 million people will suffer from a mental or neurological illness at some point in their lives. That’s about 1 in every 4 people. Due to this 1 in 4 prevalence of mental illness, it is very likely that most of us know or have met someone who has been diagnosed with a mental illness. In this course, we’ll cover some of the main and more commonly occurring and diagnosed mental disorders as they appear in the DSM5. We’ll take a look at how these disorders are viewed from the traditional psychiatric perspective as well as how mental illness is viewed from other perspectives in the field of psychology, not only in terms of their causes, but also in terms of how they are described, understood and applied by practitioners in the field. By the end of the course, students will have gained an understanding of the scope of the field of clinical psychology, including how working in the field is not always as black and white as it may first appear.
  Leerdoelen On completion of this course, students need to be able to:
  • Have a basic understanding of the role of clinical assessment in the field of mental health
  • Know the basic documented history of mental illness and the field of clinical psychology, including the different models of understanding of mental illness and the causes of mental illness. Identify the diagnostic criteria for the specific disorders covered in the course (lectures and PBL activities)
  • Have and understanding of the DSM-5: it’s history, it’s organization and the main changes to the current edition, including the dimensional approach to mental illness diagnosis
  • Understand the diagnostic process and the concept of co-morbidity
  • Understand the role of culture in understanding and interpreting mental illness and mental health
  • Have a grasp of the overlap and differences between psychology and psychiatry
  • Develop a critical perspective on the field of clinical psychology, including having developed their own opinions (based on the course material) of what mental illness and mental health are, as well as what might distinguish abnormality from normality and how the field may or may nog contribute to stigma and discrimination

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Angststoornissen behoren tot de meest voorkomende psychiatrische stoornissen en kennen vele verschijningsvormen: zo zijn er de specifieke fobie, sociale fobie, paniekstoornis, agorafobie, gegeneraliseerde angststoornis, obsessief-compulsieve stoornis en de posttraumatische stress stoornis. De studenten zullen de verschillende angststoornissen van elkaar moeten kunnen onderscheiden. Daarnaast is het de bedoeling dat studenten het ontstaan van deze stoornissen kunnen verklaren: daartoe dienen ze niet alleen te beschikken over grondige kennis van algemene conditioneringprincipes, maar ook oog te hebben voor meer specifieke processen die bij iedere stoornis apart een rol spelen.
Stress is een belangrijk thema binnen de gezondheidspsychologie. In dit blok zal vooral worden stilgestaan bij de relatie tussen stress enerzijds en lichamelijke en geestelijke gezondheidsproblemen. Denk daarbij aan hart- en vaatziekten, kanker, en maagzweren, maar ook aan depressie en angststoornissen zoals de paniek- en de post-traumatische stress stoornis.
 
Studenten maken in dit blok kennis met persoonlijkheidsdiagnostiek. In dit blok oefenen de studenten met de Eysenck Personality Profiler (EPP). Verwacht wordt dat studenten zelf de EPP invullen, scoren, en hun profiel in verband brengen met normgegevens en een persoonsbeschrijving door een naaste. Tot slot dienen studenten hier op correcte wijze verslag van te leggen, waarbij er ook aandacht is voor zelfreflectie. Leerdoelen
De algemene doelstelling van dit blok is de aanwezige kennis van angststoornissen en stress te verdiepen en uit te breiden.
Specifiek kunnen de volgende doelen voor dit blok worden geformuleerd:
  1. Kennis hebben van biologische en psychologische processen die betrokken zijn bij stress en de ervaring er van.
  2. Kennis hebben van de fenomenologie, de symptomatologie en de DSM-classificatie van de angststoornissen.
  3. Kennis hebben van de etiologie van deze stoornissen.
  4. Kennis hebben van de psychologische en farmacologische behandeling van angststoornissen.
  5. In staat zijn om wetenschappelijke artikelen over psychische stoornissen kritisch te lezen en samen te vatten.
  6. Kennis hebben van het interpreteren van een persoonlijkheidsvragenlijst aan de hand van normgegevens.
Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. M Littel', 'prof.dr. PW Jansen', 'SR van Velzen, MSc']
text:
Inhoud
De klinische psychologie richt zich op afwijkend, slecht aangepast of abnormaal gedrag dat door individuen zelf of hun omgeving als ongewenst wordt gezien. Men spreekt in dit verband ook wel van psychische, psychiatrische of psychopathologische stoornissen, of kortweg van psychopathologie. Deze stoornissen zijn veelal het resultaat van een samenspel van biologische, psychologische en sociale factoren. In aansluiting hierop houdt de klinische psychologie zich bezig met vraagstukken als 'Hoe ontstaan psychische stoornissen?', 'Hoe komt het dat ze blijven voortbestaan?', 'Welke verschillende stoornissen zijn er te onderscheiden?' en 'Op welke manieren kunnen psychopathologische stoornissen worden verholpen of voorkomen?'. Binnen dit blok gaan we in op de uiteenlopende verschijningsvormen van psychische stoornissen, op de theorieën over het ontstaan en voortduren van deze stoornissen en op de verschillende behandelingen en hun effectiviteit.
 
De kernvragen die gedurende het blok steeds weer aan de orde zullen komen zijn: waar ligt de grens tussen normaal en abnormaal, hoe ontstaat een stoornis en wat is er aan te doen?

Het blok is een onderdeel van de eisen voor het behalen van de Basisaantekening Psychodiagnostiek van het Nederlands Instituut van Psychologen (NIP).
 
Leerdoelen Het blok "Normaal of abnormaal?" gaat over afwijkend gedrag van mensen en geeft een inleiding in het vakgebied van de klinische psychologie. Aan de hand van voorbeelden uit de praktijk worden belangrijke psychische stoornissen bestudeerd, waaronder angststoornissen, eetstoornissen, stemmingsstoornissen en psychotische stoornissen. Na afloop van het blok kent de student van de meest voorkomende stoornissen het klinisch beeld en de diagnostische criteria, de theorieën over etiologie alsmede de empirische bevindingen die de theorie steunen dan wel tegenspreken, de gangbare therapieën en de effectiviteit daarvan. Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

college: Erasmus University College
lecturers: ['D.H.J. Pols', 'dr. M Martinez Claros', 'dr. MA Hartman']
text:
Inhoud In this course, which will be taught in Dutch, you will acquire the basic skills required to establish and lead a consultation as a physician. The course consists of two types of sessions that overlap Quads 1, 2, 3 and 4 of year 3: (1) Clinical reasoning (Klinisch redeneren, KR) and (2) Consultation (Consultvoering, CV). During the clinical reasoning sessions, you will learn how to make a diagnosis, after examining and analysing a patient’s complaints. You will learn what the importance is of knowing what kind of questions the physician should ask to obtain crucial and relevant information. In addition, you will learn which diseases can be the cause of a specific complaint, and how to make an accurate diagnosis by physical examinations and diagnostic tests. In the Consultation sessions, you will be able to practice the aforementioned skills. You will learn how to approach and interview patients, how to perform a physical examination, and how to interpret your findings. Due to the practical nature of the course, the assessment will be based mainly on practical exams performed in Quad 4. Leerdoelen The students will acquire the basic skills required to:

- Establish and lead an anamnesis as a physician
- Establish and lead a physical examination as a physician
- Make a differential diagnosis
- Make decisions regarding to diagnostic tests

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['dr. D. Bos', 'dr. L. Chaker', 'prof. dr. M.A. Ikram']

course_title: Close Reading Nietzsche: The Gay Science
college: Erasmus University College
text: Inhoud This course spans the entire academic year – starting in quad 1 and ending in quad 4. During the course we come together for seven (7) sessions in a seminar setting (mixing ‘close reading sessions’ and ‘discussion’) and throughout the year you will read - from cover to cover - one of the major works by one of the pivotal thinkers in continental philosophy: Friedrich Nietzsche. You may have heard about him – and if you haven’t, you probably heard about one of his famous philosophical concepts (such as nihilism, God is Dead, the Last Man, the ‘Übermensch’, The Eternal Return of the Same, etc.). This year we read Nietzsche’s classic The Gay Science (org. 1882). Your final assignment will be a review essay.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud
Het practicum Coaching en Trainingsvaardigheden biedt een kennismaking met het ontwerpen en uitvoeren van professionaliseringstrajecten, zowel individueel (coaching) als in groepen (training). Studenten ontwerpen in kleine groepen een workshop of training en bieden deze aan aan medestudenten. Daarnaast wordt aandacht besteed aan de basisbeginselen van individuele coaching van professionals. Leerdoelen
Aan het einde van dit practicum zijn studenten in staat om:
  • op een methodisch verantwoorde wijze een professionaliseringsactiviteit te ontwerpen en begeleiden, rekening houdend met verschillende culturele en sociaal-economische achtergronden (eindtermen 8, 9, 10, 11);
  • communicatieve basisvaardigheden toe te passen bij de begeleiding van individuele en groepsgewijze professionaliseringsactiviteiten, rekening houdend met verschillende culturele en sociaal-economische achtergronden (eindtermen 11, 16-19).

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud In this course you will study the mental processes involved in digital media processing. Four basic cognitive functions will be covered:
•             Attention
•             Memory
•             Comprehension
•             Thinking
 
Among the topics that will be addressed are the following. Do people have an attentional bias for negative information? Do people forget information once it has been discredited? To what extent does conspiracy thinking rely on the same mechanisms we use to comprehend information? Why are the digital media a fertile soil for the spread of misinformation and conspiracy theories? How do our cognitive biases impact our social media use? In what ways can scientists research these issues? How can we minimize the negative impact of digital media messages on our cognitive system? Leerdoelen The main objective of this course is for you to gain a basic understanding of the interaction between cognitive processes and the digital media. Students will be introduced to important theories behind basic cognitive processes, such as attention, memory, comprehension, and thinking. You will become familiar with empirical research on digital media use that is informed by these theories to address questions concerning topics such as misinformation, desinformation, conspiracy thinking, and thinking biases, as well as how to counter the negative impact of these processes.  At the end of this course, you will be familiar with major theories of cognitive information processing. You will be able to apply these theories to aspects of digital media use and thus acquire an understanding of digital media processing. You will have learned how psychologists conduct a variety of research tools, including surveys, experiments, and data mining, to understand how the digital media affect our thought processes. Furthermore, you will gain experience in critically evaluating research on cognition and the digital media. Finally, you will be able to think about  ways in which the potential negative impact of the digital media on our thought processes can be mitigated.

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud Cognitive neuroscience studies the cognitive and neural basis for such diverse mental functions as perception, action, language, attention and memory. This relatively young discipline seeks to unravel the workings of the brain. What happens in our brains when we do what we do? How is this fascinating, unbelievably complex 'microcosmos' inside our skulls organised? How do those billions of nerve cells collaborate in an organ no bigger than half a football? Thanks to advanced brain-imaging techniques available today, scientists are able to observe the human brain in action, while animal studies provide an unsurpassed understanding of underlying mechanisms. As many already know, cognitive neuroscience is the discipline of the future. Leerdoelen After completing this course, the student can
  • apply knowledge about basic neuroscience anatomy and physiology;
  • relate cognitive phenomena to biological processes;
  • distinguish the different forms of memory and their biological basis;
  • describe the neurological processes involved in sleep/waking transition
  • describe the hierarchy in decision making and its biological basis;
  • describe the mechanisms behind overt and covert attention;
  • describe the neural mechanisms behind emotions;
  • relate evolutionarily primitive neural reward mechanisms to human sexual behaviour
  • conduct behavioural experiments in a cognitive neuroscience context;

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud We have nearly 8 billion people on earth, and all of us think. But why do we think? How do we think? And what happens if we stop thinking?
This course explores the answers to these profound questions. It will go further than the course ‘Brain & Behaviour’ as it will introduce concepts like schemas, mental imagery, categorisation and language, to understand how the content of thoughts are established. Furthermore, this course delves into memory and attention. In addition, it will introduce the study of complex thinking abilities, such as problem solving, reasoning and decision making, and looks at the deterioration of cognitive processes: What happens if we are unable to think properly?

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud
Menselijke cognitie kan beschouwd worden als een snelle weg waarlangs wij ons aan veranderende omstandigheden in onze omgeving aanpassen, naast de tragere methoden van genetische mutatie en (operant) leren. Hoe helpt aandacht ons efficiënt met de informatie uit onze externe en interne omgeving om te gaan, en wat gebeurt er als aandacht faalt? Kennis en kennisrepresentatie vormen een tweede thema. Relevante vragen daarbij zijn: op welke wijze beelden wij informatie uit onze omgeving innerlijk af en hoe gebruiken we de kennis bij het interpreteren van de wereld om ons heen? De structuur en het functioneren van onze geheugens is een derde onderwerp. Hoe wordt informatie onthouden voor de korte en lange termijn? Wat gebeurt er als we herinneringen ophalen? Het laatste thema betreft redeneren en denken. Zijn er wetmatigheden te onderkennen in ons redeneren? Hoe denkt de expert en hoe de beginner in een bepaald domein?
Leerdoelen
Het blok biedt een introductie in de centrale onderwerpen van de cognitieve psychologie. Hierbij spelen cognitieve processen als begrijpen, kennisverwerving en kennisrepresentatie, aandacht, herinneren, denken, en probleemoplossen een centrale rol. Studenten maken kennis met het klassieke model van het informatieverwerkende systeem dat aan deze processen ten grondslag ligt.
Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud
In dit blok komen de meest recente neurowetenschappelijke theorieën en bevindingen op het gebied van aandacht, executieve functies, emoties, en motoriek aan bod. De lokalisatie, lateralisatie en organisatie van de verschillende hersenfuncties zullen worden behandeld. Ook wordt aandacht besteed aan de gehanteerde technieken, variërend van diermodellen tot humaan beeldvormend onderzoek zoals bijvoorbeeld met functionele MRI. Tevens zal worden ingegaan op de praktische toepassing van deze neurowetenschappelijke methoden en bevindingen.
Leerdoelen
Kennis van en inzicht in de biologische basis van cognitie en emotie; het gebruik van moderne beeldvormende technieken en toepassingen van neurowetenschappelijke kennis.
Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. SRJM van Bohemen', 'prof.dr. J van der Waal']
text:
Inhoud Deze cursus beoogt studenten dieper kennis te laten maken met de vier hoofdvragen van de sociologie: modernisering, ongelijkheid, cohesie en identiteit. Studenten maken kennis met verschillende hedendaagse toonaangevende discussies binnen deze vier thema’s, en leren reflecteren op diverse prominente onderzoeksproblemen.

Aan de hand van deze verdieping in de centrale thema’s van de sociologie, wordt aandacht besteed aan de vertaalslag van sociologische theorie naar empirie. De student leert hoe puzzels binnen de thema’s modernisering, ongelijkheid, cohesie en identiteit kunnen worden onderzocht met behulp van empirisch onderzoek. Naast het behandelen van voorbeelden van empirisch onderzoek binnen deze vier thema’s, leren studenten hoe ze zelf theoretische begrippen kunnen aanwenden voor de formulering van empirisch toetsbare vragen of verwachtingen.
  Leerdoelen Na succesvol afronden van dit vak kunnen studenten:
  • Prominente sociologische theorieën rondom cohesie en identiteit uitleggen;
  • Centrale begrippen binnen de sociologie van cohesie en identiteit beschrijven en toepassen op hedendaagse maatschappelijke vraagstukken;
  • Prominente sociologische debatten omtrent cohesie en identiteit in hedendaagse westerse samenlevingen toelichten en analyseren;
  • Hedendaagse maatschappelijke verschijnselen gebruiken om sociologische theorieën en empirisch onderzoek rondom cohesie en identiteit te reproduceren, contextualiseren en bekritiseren.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud Combinatorial optimisation deals with finding an optimal solution from a finite set of feasible solutions. Since enumerating this set is practically infeasible in general, one tries to exploit the problem structure to find an optimal solution in a computationally efficient way. In this course, we develop techniques for combinatorial optimisation problems. These techniques include:
  • Branch-and-bound
  • Lagrangean relaxation
  • Maximum flow algorithm
  • Hongarian method
  • Dynamic programming
Leerdoelen
  • To recognise and model combinatorial optimisation problems as integer programming problems.
  • To understand the basic theory and techniques to solve combinatorial optimisation problems.
  • To master the basic techniques to solve combinatorial optimisation problems.
  • To be able to implement the basic solution techniques in a software package.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud De combinatorische optimalisering houdt zich bezig met het vinden van een optimale oplossing uit een eindige verzameling van toegelaten oplossingen. Omdat volledige enumeratie van deze verzameling vaak onpraktisch is door het zeer grote aantal toegelaten oplossingen, probeert men gericht te zoeken naar een optimale oplossing door gebruik te maken van de aanwezige structuur. In dit college worden oplossingsmethoden voor combinatorische optimaliseringsproblemen behandeld. Technieken die worden behandeld zijn:
  • Branch-and-bound
  • Lagrange relaxatie
  • Maximum stroom algoritme
  • Hongaarse methode
  • Dynamisch programmeren
Leerdoelen
  • Het herkennen en modelleren van combinatorisch optimaliseringsproblemen als discrete optimaliseringsproblemen.
  • Het begrijpen van de basistheorieën en -technieken om combinatorisch optimaliseringsproblemen op te lossen.
  • Het beheersen van de basistechnieken om combinatorisch optimaliseringsproblemen op te lossen.
  • In staat zijn de basisoplossingstechnieken toe te passen in een softwarepakket.

college: Erasmus School of Law
Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['dr. FL Stevens', 'prof.mr. FGM Smeele', 'prof.mr.dr. W de Wit']
text:
Inhoud Commercial Law focuses on the contract of sale as the Master plan governing the organization of international commercial transactions. In it, the parties not only provide rules about when and where to deliver what quantity of which commodity for what price, but also for who should contract for transportation and insurance, as well as for payment and/or financing of the commercial transaction. Together, all these commercial contracts build a cluster with dynamics of its own. A key role is played by the documents reflecting these contracts. To name a few, the Bill of Exchange, the Bill of Lading, the Insurance Policy or Insurance Certificate, the Letter of Credit and the Letter of Indemnity. All these documents convey the message that in international commerce, contracts generally involve and affect third parties. From the moment of issuance, most of these documents are meant to pass from hand to hand until they reach their final destination where they will play their part. Each contract has certain peculiarities in accordance with the requirements of international trade. Attention will be given to standardized contract forms and customary abbreviations such as CIF, FOB, CAD LC and so on. Other topics to be discussed include:

- The phenomenon of negotiability of documents;
- The various roles played by the bill of lading and the implications of the presentation rule;
- The abstract payment obligation of a bank under a letter of credit or a letter of undertaking and the so-called strict conformity rule as applied by banks in their handling of commercial documents: strict to the letter of their instructions;
- Insurance for the benefit of (as yet unknown) persons interested in the goods.

Much of international trade is subjected to international Conventions and powerful customs and standardized contracts, often subject to English law and London arbitration. As of consequence these international standards will form an important basis for our studies into commercial law. Leerdoelen After completion of this course, the student can interpret and analyse critically, the main aspects of an international commercial transaction in relation to sale of goods, documents of title, banking, transport, insurance and customs law according to English law and from a civil law perspective, taking into account important international uniform law conventions. Further, the student will be able to develop a personal point of view, enter into a discussion, observe and analyse important developments, with regard to this topic and is able to apply his knowledge, to a given set of facts (case).

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Commodities are critical in the global economy as they literally power the world, feed the planet and provide the essential inputs in all the devices (e.g. smartphones) and household appliances (e.g. shampoo) that make our lives easy. Commodity trading involves the transformation of commodities in time (through storage), space (through shipping) and form (through processing). Commodity trading firms (CTFs) such as Vitol, Trafigura and Cargill are for a large part responsible for the supply and delivery of commodities to their clients, often large manufacturing firms, in which they take upon (and offset) various forms of risks (e.g. price volatility, geopolitics, the weather, foreign currency exchange and operational risks such as delay in delivery) for their clients. Commodity trading thus involves highly dynamic information-intensive tasks and capabilities in the field of logistics, finance and technology.
No better place to study this than in Rotterdam: Europe’s gateway for the global trade in physical commodities. Rotterdam forms the heart of the ARA-region (Amsterdam-Rotterdam-Antwerp), a global price reference point for crude oil and used as geographical benchmark in many commodity delivery contracts and freight prices. Commodity traders make use of the port to ship the commodities to markets and many have actual logistical assets (tank storage and warehouses) and processing operations (i. c. refineries)  in the port in addition to the trade desks, supply chain support functions, head offices or holdings in the city.
  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
The aim of this course is to provide a clear understanding of the important role that commodity traders play in global supply chains and to gain both hard analytical skills and soft skills required to work in dynamic, multinational commodity trading operations.

After the course, students should be able to:
1.    Understand worldwide supply and demand patterns of the most important commodity product groups (energy, metals/minerals, agriculturals)
2.    Comprehend the way commodity markets (physical and derivative) function and the role that commodity trading firms play in the worldwide physical delivery of commodities, including contracting, financing and shipping.
3.    Comprehend the various forms of risks involved in commodity trading and how these can be mitigated.
4.    Analyze specific commodity markets and synthesize these analyses into (short term) trading strategies and (long term) strategic decision-making
5.    Present analytical results to a professional audience.  

The assessment consists of an individual assignment (essay), a group assignment (business case), and an individual written exam. The elective will be concluded with a College Tour-style meeting, in which students and business leaders will engage in thought provoking discussions.

Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud As the world’s urban population grows, the living conditions in cities differ drastically. Socio-economic divides, disabilities, and differences linked to gender, race and ethnicity have important consequences for people’s everyday experiences in/with the city and for their sense of belonging.

This course focuses on the key role of communication in sustaining and challenging these inequalities. The starting point is the acknowledgement that (economic) equality and social (e.g., cultural, racial, ethnic, gender) difference can go hand in hand. This means that socio-economic justice is not about everyone being the same, but about gender, ethnic, racial and other differences being properly recognized and represented. Recognition and representation are communication rights: They enable social groups to have a fair say in society and in the distribution of its resources.


In the case of Rotterdam, consider, for example, how the city is drawn and labeled in tourist maps and business brochures; how “normal” Rotterdammers and/or “foreigners” look in public campaigns; how the city inhabitants and their problems are portrayed in the news; what art deserves city funding; and what is the local history taught in schools. Moreover, who gets to decide about these issues? Which ways of being Rotterdammer and perspectives on the city prevail?
 
In dealing with these issues—not only in relation to Rotterdam, but to cities around the world—the course strongly relies on students’ own background and experiences. It pays attention to both the local and the cross-national from an interdisciplinary and critical perspective.
  Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding  of:
  • Critical and interdisciplinary theoretical perspectives on social inequality.
  • Basic communicational dimensions of social inequality.
  • Communicative practices related to specific inequalities and efforts to contest them in contemporary urban spaces.
Students have developed the skills to:
  • Critically reflect upon, compare and articulate the strengths and weaknesses of different perspectives on the topic.
  • Take and defend theoretical positions.
  • Independently apply academic concepts and theories covered in the course to contemporary case studies and their own work.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Contents, course description
​
Communicating sustainability is of key importance for corporations, non-profit organizations and activists alike. However, it is increasingly difficult for sustainability advocates to communicate sustainability-related messages and for audiences to discern what initiatives and messages are credible, important or relevant. A number of conflating trends create immense challenges for effective sustainability communication. For instance, proponents of fake news regularly use misinformation tactics to confuse audiences about environmental issues, literarily polluting the information landscape. Moreover, seemingly every organization now brands their operations as sustainable. Nevertheless, we live in a time that calls for immediate climate action, with thousands of initiatives underway at the global, national and local levels. Amongst these initiatives, it may be challenging for sustainability advocates to construct clear and distinct strategies and campaigns for communicating sustainability.

The goal of this course is to broaden participants’ understanding of communicating sustainability. Participants will learn basic concepts, theories and practices for communicating sustainability, and given an opportunity to apply and critically evaluate these. The course takes a broad perspective on communicating sustainability, by exploring topics such as crisis communication, stakeholder engagement, advocacy and activism, issue emergence, greenwashing and integrated reporting. The course includes lectures on key concepts, and guest lectures by both academic and professional experts, case studies, and skills workshops. Most importantly, participants will have the opportunity for hands-on work as communication experts and develop a crisis communication plan. These plans will be presented at the end of the course to corporate communication specialists in the field. The course is suitable for any Masters level student interested in the topic.
Leerdoelen
Learning goals
 
After completing this course, the participant will be able to:
•    Understand of the role of sustainability communication and master relevant related concepts such as crisis communication, stakeholder engagement, issue emergence, greenwashing, and integrated reporting.
•    Evaluate a communication strategy for a sustainability-related issue, and apply concepts such as framing, rhetoric and discourse during the analysis
•    Be able to create an operable sustainability related crisis communication plan under time-pressure
•    Be able to create and present to external professionals an operable stakeholder engagement plan on a sustainability issue.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. AFM Krijnen', 'dr. AG Fokkema', 'dr. CS Ritter', 'dr. DC Ramos Antunes da Silva', 'dr. J Kneer', 'dr. PS Cameron-Gardos', 'dr. WK McCarthy', 'JR van Keulen, MA', 'P Mashigo, MA', 'prof.dr. MPA Bouman', 'TCTM Loudon']
text:
Inhoud Students will have a general understanding of 'ethics' for the media professional. They will be introduced to different perspectives in (social) philosophy with an emphasis on different modes of ethical reasoning. This understanding will enable the students to evaluate how well or how poorly standards in the field (e.g., professional ethics in journalism or public relations), are constructed and formulated. Students will not only be able to identify the ethical perspectives underlying these standards, but also to identify the different ethical argumentations implied within these. Through readings and class discussions connected to real life cases, students will be trained in ethical reasoning and form personal ethical underpinnings for their future careers.

Note: The lectures of this course are mandatory. Leerdoelen Students have advanced their knowledge, understanding and awareness of:
  • ethical thinking in general;
  • the cultural and historical diversity of ethical principles;
  • ethical principles guiding professional ethical standards in the field of media and communication.
Students have developed the skills to:
  • critically examine and evaluate ethical principles guiding professional ethical standards in the field of media and communication;
  • formulate and defend their own ethical principles and reflect on their own intercultural competencies.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['DE Kiss, MA', 'dr. AMM Hermans', 'dr. L Zheng', 'dr. NF Lund', 'dr. Y Wang', 'RS Rocha, MSc']
text:
Inhoud
T-mobile creates a YouTube viral video by capitalizing on the already viral flashmob videos online. Marc Jacobs gains a loyal following on Twitter through his personable tweets. KLM, designs a media campaign encouraging people to ‘stewardess’ themselves, gaining significant attention with well over 55,000 new fans on Facebook in just 7 days. Whether it is electronics, fashion non-profits, all companies and organizations seem challenged by new communications possibilities in the social media era. However, most are still experimenting with their communications and some are hesitant to adapt.

This course provides an overview and application of how companies and organizations are using social media. The course examines key patterns and ongoing challenges in social media marketing based on recent empirical findings, particularly in relation to social media and reputational risk, as well as social customer relationship management. In teams, students will focus on a particular theme and choose a particular company or organization. Then, applying their academic knowledge, they will conduct a practical consulting project. The course cumulates in a pitch to the company (in class) and a final written proposal using insights gained throughout the term. This workshop will be of interest to students keen on entering the private sector as consultants and communication specialists.

Note: This course is only open to IBCoM students.
Leerdoelen Students have gained knowledge and an understanding of:
  • The management of social media communication and marketing within (international) companies and organizations
  • The needs of a particular company or organization  and their concerns regarding social media
  • Innovations and challenges in adopting social media strategies and campaigns
Students have developed the skills to:
  • Critically reflect upon international case studies and real-world social media management scenarios
  • Apply theoretical notions to practical consulting project
  • Develop a professional relationship with a company or organization
  • Implement diverse methods of collecting and analyzing customer data
  • Design and pitch a professional proposal for companies or organizations on their social media practices
  • Effectively work in internationally diverse teams and identify key patterns and ongoing challenges in social media campaigns

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['AK van Eldik, MSC MA', 'dr. DC Ramos Antunes da Silva', 'dr. EBR Timmermans', 'dr. IM Derda', 'dr. M Slot', 'M Fried, MSC MA', 'P Mashigo, MA', 'Q Huang', 'RS Rocha, MSc', 'V Balan, MSc']
text:
Inhoud The introduction and use of new communication technologies in society can never be told in just one story. It is a process of mutual shaping; society and technology influence each other, with   various outcomes, opportunities and impacts for different groups of people in various contexts. In   this course, we will look at the interplay between communication technologies and society. The course is both historical and thematic in nature and offers a critical exploration of (a selection of) cultural, social, political and economic impacts of various communication technologies on our society. Teaching methods involve a combination of lectures and tutorials. The lectures provide a guide to the subject matter and set out foundations on which students can build, while the tutorials stress active participation by the students and provide the opportunity for in-class assignments and discussion of key issues and optional topics. Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • The historical development of media and communication technologies in international perspective;
  • Themes central to the study of new media and communication technologies;
  • Social, political, cultural and economic impacts of new media and communication technologies and the forces shaping their development and use in different times and places.
Students have developed the ability and/or propensity to:
  • Critically reflect on fundamental and practical issues related to societal aspects of new media and communication technologies;
  • Formulate their own viewpoints and research questions, using relevant theoretical insights, concepts and research findings.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud The introduction and role of new communication technologies in society can never be told in just one story. It is a  process  of mutual shaping; society and technology influence  each other, with various outcomes, opportunities and impacts for  different groups  of people  in various  contexts. In this course, we will critically reflect upon the interplay between communication technologies and society. The course is both historical and thematic in nature. Students  will be  trained to  critically reflect on fundamental and practical issues related to societal aspects of new media and communication technologies, and to formulate their own viewpoints, using relevant theoretical insights, concepts and research findings. This course is completely online, online learning resources are available on Canvas, these are complemented with mandatory weekly individual and group assignments that need to be completed to meet the attendance requirements.
  Leerdoelen Students have  nowledge and understanding of:
  • The  historical development of media  and  communication technologies;
  • Theoretical perspectives and approaches utilized in the study of new media and communication technologies;
  • Social, political, cultural and economic impacts of new media and communication technologies and the  forces  shaping their  development and use  in different times  and places.
Students have the ability and/or propensity to:
  • Critically reflect on fundamental and practical issues related to societal aspects of new media and communication  technologies;
  • To formulate their own viewpoints and research questions, using relevant theoretical insights, concepts  and  research findings.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud
As this is a seminar, personal input from the students is an essential part of the classes. The instructor will illustrate how mechanisms and issues related to communication in international
relations play a role in negotiations. We will put our acquired skills into practice by organizing large- scale simulations of negotiation. Students will also be required to focus on one aspect of communication in international relations that they would like to develop into a final paper.
The ultimate aim of the seminar is not theoretical, but practical: for participants to become better ‘international communicators’.
 
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 25. IBCoM students take priority over other students.
  Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • Conceptual frameworks and theories regarding communication in international relations
  • Real-life issues, crisis communication strategies and conflict resolution attempts in international communication
Students have developed the skills to:
  • Critically review current research on international communication processes and practices
  • Analyze and reflect on developments, issues and practices in various international communications settings

course_title: Communication and Media Labour Market Orientation
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['K Vedder, MA', 'prof.dr. FMG de Jong', 'RN Mast, MA', 'RS Rocha, MSc', 'VSC van den Hout']
text:
Inhoud Graduates of the IBCoM program can take on specialized communication jobs in a variety of fields, including marketing, management, sales, corporate communications, public relations, internal communications, government, public affairs, education, journalism, the media and entertainment industries, and the art world.

This course will help IBCoM students orient on the opportunities in these professional fields, in preparation for their internships (required in the second year of the program), and for the job market after they have graduated from the program. During the lectures, guest speakers from a variety of relevant fields will present their views on the labor market in communication and media and discuss the issues that they consider key to acquiring and fulfilling particular positions or internships in their field. In the tutorial meetings students will train and develop their skills to find and prepare for an internship or job relevant to their career goals.

Note: This course is only open to IBCoM students. 

Students should have completed the course Communication and Media Practice (CM2008) before they may start with the internship (CM3040) in BA-2. Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding and awareness of:
  • Labor market prospects and career opportunities for graduates in communication and media
  • Internships opportunities for students in communication and media in the Netherlands and abroad
  • Expectations and requirements of potential employers and internship providers in a variety of relevant fields
Students have developed the skills to:
  • Define their own career goals and learning objectives
  • Orientate themselves on the (international) job and internship market
  • Search for relevant job opportunities and internships in the Netherlands and abroad
  • Apply for an (international) internship position
  • Develop an internship plan and otherwise prepare for their internship

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. A van Prooijen', 'dr. R Mittal', 'dr. S Nguyen', 'dr. Y Wang', 'I Blum, MA', 'PH Le, MSC MA', 'TAP Oomen, MSc']
text:
Inhoud In this course, we will examine communication as it relates to organizations and organizing. The course will focus on the history, major theories, and contemporary issues and dilemmas of organizations in an international and globalizing environment. Topics covered are communication processes and structure, organizational culture, leadership, branding and identity, power, teamwork, and gender in organizations. Critiques of organizational communication systems, structures and theories are also presented. Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • The main theoretical approaches, perspectives and issues in the field of organizational communication;
  • The role of communication in the functioning and performance of organizations;
  • Processes of organizational communication in a multicultural and global environment.
Students have the ability and/or propensity to:
  • Systematically analyse and critically reflect on fundamental and practical issues in the field of organizational communication
  • To communicate their viewpoints clearly and constructively, both orally and in writing;
  • Reflect on and improve their own competence in communicating in diverse organizational settings.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud In this course, we will explore communication within the context of organisations and organizing. The course will focus on the major theories, issues and dilemmas of organizations in an international environment. Topics covered are communication processes, organizational structure, organisational culture, organizational identity, power, diversity, teams and leadership.

Note: The maximum number of participants is 60
  Leerdoelen Students have the ability and/or propensity to:
  • Systematically analyse and critically reflect on fundamental and practical issues in the field of organizational communication
  • Be able to apply the theory to a variety of organizational settings and challenges
  • Be able to identify and distinguish between different perspectives from the field of organizational communication

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['A van Lienden, MA', 'BG Zerebecki, MSc', 'C Modugno, MSc', 'dr. A Paz Alencar', 'dr. DC Ramos Antunes da Silva', 'I Blum, MA', 'P Mashigo, MA', 'V Balan, MSc']
text:
Inhoud This course presents an overview of state-of-the art approaches to understanding media and communication as social forces. The first part of the course considers how media and communication feature in processes of major social change(s). It does so through the concept of mediatization, which approaches social, cultural, political and economic practices as increasingly organized around the workings and logic of the media. Case studies will illustrate how different fields and institutions are greatly affected by such media logic.
The second part of the course focuses on the different ways in which we can understand media and communication as technologies in governing the behavior of citizens in contemporary society. The course emphasizes current developments in media and communications in an international perspective to provide context and comparison. Course activities include in-depth discussion of key issues and questions, in-class assignments, presentations and discussions of student assignments and coursework. Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding  of:
  • The main theoretical perspectives and approaches to the study of the societal aspects and impacts of mediated communication;
  • The  historical development of mediated communication;
  • The social, political, cultural and economic impacts of media and the forces shaping their development and use in different times and places.
Students are able to:
  • Reflect on fundamental and practical issues related to societal aspects of mediated communication, drawing on relevant theoretical insights, concepts and research findings;
  • Formulate their own viewpoints and research.

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['dr. EA Ontanu', 'LP Defaix', 'mr.dr. E Boomsluiter', 'prof.mr.dr. JH Even', 'prof.mr.dr. MA Verbrugh']

college: Erasmus School of Law
text:
Inhoud The idea underlying this course is to present constitutional law from a comparative perspective, in order to improve the knowledge of the student's national constitutional system. For that reason, not only constitutional texts will be compared and analyzed, but also specific features of constitutional systems, such as the separation of powers, judicial review (or the absence of judicial review), federalism and the protection of human rights. Special attention will be paid to the constitutional systems of countries like the United Kingdom, Germany and France and the United States, which have served as a model for many twentieth-century constitutions. Leerdoelen Constitutional law has become increasingly important not only in the context of national legal systems, but also in an international context, as part of attempts to rebuild states that are in crisis or have become ‘failed states’ where stability and security are jeopardized, peaceful means of solving conflicts are under pressure and the rights of private citizens are not guaranteed. This course aims at increasing the familiarity of students with basic notions of constitutional law in various constitutional systems. Focus will be on a substantive theme – Democracy – and on method. Two recent books will be read with the students and discussed during class.

Students are expected to give a group presentation in which they link themes that are present in the books to constitutional questions that have arisen in their home country. There is an oral exam.

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['dr. SPF van Haperen', 'ES Graler', 'K Parmaksiz', 'OS van der Woerd, MSc', 'prof.dr. HM van de Bovenkamp', 'prof.dr. RA Bal', 'TS van Dijk, MSc']
text:
Inhoud

How can we find out why countries that are similar in many ways sometimes have very different healthcare policies? Or, the other way around, why countries that at first sight appear to be very different, turn out to have rather similar policies? The aim of this course is to provide you with theoretical perspectives and methodological tools to answer the question of how to perform a comparative health policy analysis to explain cross-country differences and similarities.

We use an institutional theory framework. Institutional theory looks at the ‘building blocks’ of society. The relationships between state, market and community differ between countries. For instance, the relative dominance of the state in country A versus the market in country B can explain differences between their healthcare policies. Institutional theory also looks at how these building blocks or the relationships between them change overtime and what the role of past decisions and human action is in causing (or blocking) change.

We use a case-oriented research design to find out what is inside the ‘black box’ of healthcare policies across countries. This is a qualitative approach, in which we are not so much interested in finding correlations or testing hypotheses, but rather in learning more about the stories behind the policies. Concepts from institutional theory will help to structure the search for information and to interpret the findings.

Grading
The paper assignment will determine 50% of the final course grade; the written exam makes up the other 50%. A minimum grade of 4.5 is required for the written exam.  

Leerdoelen

At the end of this course, you will be able to execute a comparative health policy analysis and to judge the possibilities for cross-country learning.

college: Erasmus School of Law
text:
Inhoud In this course some of the basic tenets of comparative law are dealt with. First, the focus is on classification and characteristics of the major legal systems in the world. Apart from the French, German and English systems, also non-European legal systems are discussed such as the United States. In addition, uniform law (including European harmonization) is analyzed (objectives, manifestations, instruments, uniform interpretation, organizations and coordination). Finally, the methodology of comparative legal research is discussed. Leerdoelen The objective of the course is to familiarize the participating students with the characteristics of the major legal traditions, with basic notions of uniform law (including European harmonization) and with the methodology of comparative law research.      
After completion of the course, the student should have an understanding of the characteristics and structure of the major legal traditions and of uniform law. In addition, he should be capable of doing comparative legal research. 
The student shall be assessed on the basis of knowledge or on the basis of the skill of writing a comparative law paper.

college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
text:
Inhoud Course description
Comparative public policy has become an important field of study within the Policy Sciences more in general. By promoting the exchange of knowledge, expertise and ‘best practices’ across Europe it is also playing an important role in the process of Europeanization of public policies itself. Yet, comparative public policy faces many empirical, theoretical and methodological difficulties. To overcome such difficulties, this course develops a problem solving approach to the comparative study of public policies.
 
Leerdoelen
Learning objectives
At the end of the course, students:
  • are able to discuss the difficulties as well as opportunities of comparative public policy for policy learning;
  • are familiar with the comparative dynamics of agenda setting;
  • can compare processes of policy implementation by looking at instrument choices and implementation styles;
  • are familiar with the design and execution of policy research from a comparative perspective and with instruments as international surveys, multi-case studies, benchmarking and best practices and use of international statistics

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Erasmus School of Law
text:
Inhoud Competition policy (also called "antitrust policy") is a term used broadly to describe intervention by public authorities to ensure competition in markets for goods and services. This course aims at making students familiar with the application of economic arguments in European competition law. Comparisons with U.S. antitrust law are included where appropriate for a better understanding of cases and the implications of legislation and court rulings on economic efficiency.
This course is open for EMLE students only.

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['dr. AF Roos', 'dr. RGM Kemp', 'dr.ir. RCMH Douven', 'prof.dr. M Varkevisser']
text:
Inhoud Following years of controls, rationing and expenditure caps, many countries introduce market-based health care reforms. Competitive interactions between health care providers and payers create incentives that affect market players’ behavior and the price, quality and quality of health care services. This is especially true in the United States, where the majority of total health expenditures are privately financed and prices, quantities and qualities for health care services are determined by market interactions. But competitive forces also shape strategic interactions in health care systems which are mostly publically financed and where prices are regulated (for example, the British NHS).

In this course, students are introduced to determinants of market structure, prices, quality, provider networks and competition in health insurance and provider markets. Unique attributes in health care not only affect the functioning of market-based health care systems, but also complicate competition enforcement. Therefore, competition (or: antitrust) enforcement in the health care sector is also extensively discussed.

The central aim of this course is to study:
  • the functioning and performance of competitive health care systems
  • the use and adequacy of competition enforcement in health care
  • the challenges related to competition (enforcement) in health care.
To that end, the course introduces students to state-of-the-art concepts and literature in the field of industrial organization of health care markets.

Course structure
The course consists of 12 meetings of 90 minutes with problem-based interactive lectures.

Some classes will be taught by guest teachers. Leerdoelen The central aim of this course is to study:
  • the functioning and performance of competitive health care markets
  • the role of EU competition law and its national counterparts in health care
  • what theoretical and empirical challenges policymakers and antitrust agencies face, when introducing competition and applying competition law in health care

By the end of this course the student is able to:
  • Evaluate the functioning and performance of competitive health care markets
  • Assess the use and adequacy of the enforcement of main competition instruments in health care:
    • the cartel prohibition
    • the prohibition on abuse of dominance
    • merger control
  • Understand the theoretical & empirical challenges related to competition and the enforcement of competition policy in health care

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus MC Academie
Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['dr. M.J. Negrello', 'E. Buitenhuis - Linssen', 'L.M.R. Nijs - de Langen']

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud Most students are comfortable using commercially available software, like Excel or Adobe Photoshop. However, the power of being able to use computers expands dramatically when one learns how to think like a software engineer and how to design and even write one’s own computer programs. Programming, or “coding”, is an essential skill for a large number of academic and commercial activities. This course is an introduction to programming simple algorithms that can be extremely useful throughout anyone’s career. This course aims to provide students with an understanding of the role computation can play in solving problems. It also aims to help students, regardless of their future direction, to feel justifiably confident of their ability to write programs that allow them to accomplish useful goals. The course uses the Matlab (M) programming language as an example, as it is easy to learn and useful in many scientific fields, and the acquired coding skills and the programmer’s mindset will be easily transferred to other programming languages. Leerdoelen Learning Objectives:

• Illustrate the value of computing and computer programming 
• Become familiar with programming and the programming environment of MATLAB 
• Apply the use of programming to a set of problems
• Learn how to continue learning how to program

college: Erasmus University College

<body>Coding is an essential skill for a large number of academic and commercial activities. This course introduces students to the programming language Python 3 (P). This language is widely used in academia, is open and free, and allows one to use a programming language used by a large worldwide community, as well as companies like Google, Facebook, Instagram, Spotify, Quora, Netflix, Dropbox & Reddit. Python 3 is well-supported and well-documented and allows for a number of things that other packages, e.g Matlab, do not. For example like picking one’s own Integrated Development Environment. The course Computer Science I (or Computer Science M) is not a prerequisite, but can be helpful because the way of thinking like a programmer is also taught in Computer Science I/M. Students will be offered lectures alongside tutorials during which they will work on exercises and assignments.</body>
</html>

Leerdoelen
