	<body>
		At the end of the course, the students will acquire sufficient knowledge in order to apply techniques from informatics, computer science and programming to their own research. </body>
</html>

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud The course starts by introducing various Computer Science topics relevant for Business Analytics. After that, the phenomenon of Big Data is presented, followed by the Semantic Web as a set of technologies bringing structure to Big Data. As a large amount of Big Data resides on the Web, techniques for extracting information from online sources will also be discussed. Additionally, in order to be able to query relational databases, the SQL query language will be studied.

As means to process Big Data we will look at parallel computing models, focusing on the Map-Reduce parallel computing style. Also, with the purpose of reducing the number of computations for finding similar items (a fundamental data mining problem), we will describe Locality-Sensitive Hashing.

In order to better assimilate the topics covered during lectures, the students will work in teams on several assignments on the discussed topics. The students will also write a report describing the proposed solutions. Leerdoelen
  • Have an overview of Computer Science topics (e.g., Machine Learning, Data Mining, Query Languages, Parallel Algorithms, etc.) relevant for Business Analytics.
  • Know Computer Science techniques (e.g., Semantic Web, Locality-Sensitive Hashing, SQL, Map-Reduce, etc.) applicable for Business Analytics.
  • Exploit Computer Science techniques for building Business Analytics solutions.

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['drs. EC Smit - Bennemeer', 'mr. C van Noortwijk']
text:
Inhoud The course focuses upon certain concrete legal problems that are connected with the use of information technology in society. Examples are: downloading music and movies from the internet; the legal protection of computer software, databases and data; ecommerce and electronic markets; privacy protection and computer crime; legal questions of ‘Social media’ and the liability of intermediary service providers. Students will learn to analyse these problems and examine possible solutions within the context of their own national legal system. The problems of integrating technological developments in areas that have always been paper-based, and the role and use of 'electronic signatures' in these areas will also be examined. In addition to these practical aspects, the impact of technology on the development of legal principles will be dealt with.
 
In the digital world of the Internet, today's lawyers frequently encounter problems and questions, but also new possibilities related to information technology. Lawyers in private practice, company lawyers or lawyers in managing functions are expected to be able to deal with such issues.
    
Furthermore, information technology has given rise to new possibilities for legal practice as well as for performing (empirical) legal research. Several of such new possibilities will be discussed during this course. Among these are new ways to increase legal knowledge, as well as to manage this knowledge and to apply it in practice. By working on two practical assignments, students will have the opportunity to perform ‘jurimetrics research’ and to build and use so-called ‘legal knowledge based systems’.
  Leerdoelen
The aim of this course is twofold:
•    to familiarize students with the social changes brought about by the 'Information Society', and to place these within a legal context;
•    to assess the impact of IT developments for the legal profession (sometimes referred to as ‘LegalTech’) and to gain insight in new tools and methodologies (for instance, for performing legal research) that are (or will be) available to lawyers.
 
After the course, students will be able to
•    understand and describe the way in which technology is developing;
•    formulate legal questions and problems relevant to our current ‘Information Society’;
•    provide solutions to these questions and problems;
•    discern the essential characteristics of the internet, as far as these are legally relevant;
•    assess the impact of IT on legal practice;
•    perform empirical research, as a group member, with respect to (data relating to) legal decision making;
•    explain the importance of proper knowledge management for legal organizations, and the role information systems can play for that.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Categories and concepts make up the knowledge people have about things and people in the world. Being able to make a connection between our earlier experiences and new interactions with the environment ensure that we can recognise and understand new things and people. For most people this is a fairly simple process which runs largely automatically, but understanding it from a psychological viewpoint is highly complicated. Four broad topics will be covered during this course: Learning categories and the formation of prototypes and stereotypes, and the consequences for categorizing things and people. The effect of brain damage or abnormalities on categorisation and concept representations, with a special focus on deficits that result in the inability to recognize particular categories of things such as animals or human faces. Embodied cognition, which will address the question whether bodily sensations or actions are involved in the representations of categories. The grounding of concepts in the brain, addressing the question where and how conceptual knowledge is represented by the brain, and which methods can be used to investigate this question. Leerdoelen Students learn the most important theories and empirical data on the way people represent their knowledge and the influence this has on behaviour. Attention will also be devoted to research methods both in theory and practice. At the end of the course, students should be able to understand, describe, and critically compare theories of categorization and concept representations. They should be able to understand, describe, and critically evaluate studies that test such theories.
  Belangrijk om te weten English serves as the language of instruction for all tutorials and lectures.

course_title: Concepts and Methods of Law and Economics
college: Erasmus School of Law
text: Inhoud This course offers an introduction to the basic concepts and methods of law and economics. It illustrates the broad utility of these tools by way of applications to the analysis of various core areas of law. This course does not aim to develop practical skills or new insights, but rather to show the broad utility of economic analysis of law. By combining examples from various areas of law, students will learn that the economic approach to law provides a unified vision of the law, tying together diverse areas of the law into a common theoretical structure.

course_title: Conflict Analysis and Transformation: A Governance Perspective
college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
lecturers: ['dr. HM Hintjens', 'dr. N van Stapele', 'dr. SMS Jayasundara - Smits', 'prof.dr. SM Murshed']

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud In today's world, war between states has become a rarity, whereas violent conflict within national boundaries is of growing concern. The causes and dynamics of civil wars, and other types of intra-state conflicts, require a different understanding than classical wars. Conflicts are increasingly complex, featuring multiple parties, transnational dynamics, and strategies to resolve them.
 
The course focuses on contemporary conflicts and is structured around three parts: (I) how conflicts arise, (II) how they can be managed, and (III) how they can be transformed and resolved. Borrowing from fields such as International Relations, Political Science, Sociology, Psychology, history, anthropology, Law, this course has a distinctly interdisciplinary outlook.
 
A variety of violent conflicts are featured ranging from ethnic, electoral, ethnic, resource-based and secessionist. By adopting a case study-approach, we will attempt to understand the causes of conflict as well as techniques and interventions developed to end and resolve them such as peacekeeping, mediation, and transitional justice. Finally, you will gain tools to understand and analyse conflict, and gain practical experience in negotiating a resolution to a conflict by means of a simulation game. Leerdoelen
After completing this course, you will:
  • have basic knowledge of various types of conflict in the contemporary world;
  • be familiar with different conflict models and able to apply these models, concepts and theories to a range of conflicts;
  • have acquired an understanding of the main methods and tools used in conflict resolution;
  • have acquired basic skills in conflict analysis, problem-solving and negotiation

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

To bring business closer to your academic education and enhance your understanding of the business world in practice the consultancy project is part of the program. In the consultancy project you are challenged to analyse a real-life problem coming from a business-client and understand the specific needs in and of a client organization. In a group of approximately 6 students you will be asked to help a client solving a problem by developing new and sustainable recommendations. This process takes place in a project-like work setting in intensive contact with the client. You are expected to understand the clients’ needs, scope and narrow down the problem into a researchable question, develop and use a suitable theoretical framework, collect data and explore potential solutions and make recommendations. The projects often take place within a context with various stakeholders. Hence, dealing with a variety of different stakeholder is part of the project.

Next to problem-solving skills necessary in this project team cooperation and leadership in and of a team are relevant aspects in this project. To reflect on the team process and improve on your team behaviour various challenge and reflection moments are built into this 4 month process. The project team is invited to assess their members’ behaviour and critically reflect on possible improvements.
 

This course is worth 6 EC and runs from blocks 3 through 4.
Leerdoelen
  • Analytical skills: Dealing with a high amount of information in a short time in an (formerly) unknown domain and gain/maintain an overview
  • Analytical skills: Being able to define, scope, analyse and structure an (formerly) unknown and ill-defined problem
  • Problem-solving skills: Develop consistent, relevant and sustainable recommendations for the client based on high professional standards and understand that there is no right or wrong
  • Managerial skills: Think independently and behave autonomously: working on problems – not following instructions
  • Managerial skills: manage and satisfy the various requirements from stakeholders
  • Managerial skills: Make use of the cross-cultural and disciplinary diversity in a team
  • Leadership skills: experience and reflect on your impact on a team process and think about improvements
  • Getting socialized into the business world

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Veel organisaties lopen tegen vraagstukken aan die zij niet zelf kunnen oplossen. Vaak ontbeert het hen aan de kennis of expertise die nodig is. Op dergelijke momenten kunnen zij een consultant inhuren. Het kennisvoordeel van een consultant kan betrekking hebben op specialistische kennis van een industrie of vakgebied, een specifieke methode of opgebouwde ervaringen.

In dit consultancyproject, dat een belangrijk onderdeel vormt van het pMiM-programma, gaan studenten in groepen van vier studenten intensief aan de slag om een bestaand probleem voor één private of (semi-) publieke organisatie op te lossen. Net als in het echt, komt deze “opdracht” uit het netwerk van de consultant. Dat kan de organisatie zijn waar een van de studenten werkzaam is (met als voordeel dat deze organisatie extra rendement krijgt op hun medewerker die het pMiM-programma doorloopt) maar dat is niet noodzakelijk (al is het wel aanbevelenswaardig om een organisatie te vinden waar men contacten heeft zodat men vlot kan starten). Het is echter uitgesloten dat men een adviesopdracht doet voor zichzelf (want dan is men klant en consultant tegelijkertijd). Samen met de klant (opdrachtgever) wordt er gekeken naar een vraagstuk waar de consultants mee aan de slag gaan.

Dit vraagstuk dient te liggen op het gebied van een of meerdere van de VN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Zo slaan we meerdere vliegen in één klap. We helpen de organisatie en de samenleving. Niet voor niets wil RSM organisaties stimuleren tot een “force for positive change”. Alle teams werken dan ook vanuit het gezamenlijke adviesbureau “SDG Consultancy”, waarbij studenten de adviesteams vormen en de docent de adviespartner.

Het algemeen doel van het consultancyproject is om op een professionele wijze, met hulp van wetenschappelijke inzichten, een echt, weerbarstig probleem voor een organisatie op te lossen, om te leren samen te werken in multidisciplinaire en/of multiculturele teams, een probleem goed te definiëren, te structuren en af te bakenen en om een consultancyproces van begin tot eind te doorlopen zodat tot handzame aanbevelingen voor de organisatie van de opdrachtgever wordt gekomen. De implementatie van de aanbevelingen hoort niet tot de scope van dit project.  

Dit vak bestaat uit 6 EC en loopt in blok 4 en 5, jaar 1

 
Leerdoelen
De leerdoelen van het consultancyproject zijn:
Na afronding van het vak is de student tot het volgende in staat:
  • Omgaan met grote hoeveelheid informatie in een korte tijd, op een onbekend terrein en in een onbekende setting en hierin het overzicht te krijgen en bewaren.
  • Identificeren, analyseren, vaststellen en structureren van een onbekend probleem.
  • Ontwikkelen van een relevante en bestendige oplossing voor de klant gebaseerd op professionele standaarden en het begrijpen van de managementimplicaties van die oplossing. 
  • Oplossen van een probleem, in plaats van het opvolgen van instructies, door onafhankelijk denken en autonoom handelen. 
  • Managen van en tegemoetkomen aan de verschillende behoeften en verwachtingen van belanghebbenden.
  • Gebruikmaken van de culturele en disciplinaire diversiteit in een team.
  • Reflecteren op de eigen impact op het teamproces. 
  • Bekendraken met de organisatiecontext.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Consumers are confronted in their daily lives with numerous marketing actions. Companies and manufacturers use media to pursuade consumers to buy their products or to use their services. To understand the idea behind these communciation messages you will learn in this course different concepts and theories from the behavioral sciences. For example you will learn how consumers make decisions and how they learn and remember information. You will also learn how consumers are persuaded or motivated. Moreover you will learn how consumers form attitudes about products and you will get insight into how all these theories and concepts are used by companies in their media communication and marketing strategies. In this course all students make a personal portfolio of magazine advertisements. Students will analyze these advertisements in order to gain insight into important concepts that are covered throughout the course. Moreover, this assignment will help you to see how and why marketing practice may illustrate and support consumer behavior theories, as well as how practice may contradict these theories.
 
Note:
  • This course is not accessible for students who have already completed the CM2072 or CM2272 course.
Leerdoelen The purpose of this course is to introduce you to the study of consumer behavior. We will examine many concepts and theories from the behavioral sciences and analyze their usefulness for developing marketing strategies. The goal is to teach you these key concepts and to develop your ability to apply them in analyzing marketing situations and developing appropriate marketing strategies.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud The course focuses on consumer/audience behavior, more specifically people’s attitudes towards specific businesses/organizations/products/services/artists, what factors contribute to their attraction to those products, and why they continue to make the same choices. On the other hand, the course topic is also meant to research upon and give a better understanding regarding individuals’ ‘attachment’ to specific brands, and possible reasons behind their refusal to acknowledge the quality of others.
Based on a theory-practice perspective, the course will introduce students to specific persuasion tools, used in both media and advertising for business purposes, giving them an insight on what to look for when analyzing specific topics, and will also encourage them to find examples to which the theoretical concepts can be applied.
Seminars will be divided into two main parts, the understanding of theoretical concepts, and discussing them in relation to practical examples. Four assignments will be given during the 8-week seminars, and the final assessment will consist of a comment paper and the presentation of that paper. During the seminars, formats for qualitative analysis research will be introduced to students, with the expectation that their final exam hand-ins will be arranged according to those formats. Leerdoelen Students have the ability to:
  • develop their analytical skills, both individually (through assignments and exam) and in teams (during seminar debates);
  • gain a better understanding of qualitative research methods, in the form of a critical comment paper at the end of the term;
  • develop their debating skills, opinion expression, argument defense and confrontation, and also presentation abilities.
Students will have knowledge and understanding of:
  • theoretical analysis methods;
  • literature reviews in accordance to specific topics;
  • integration methods of reviewed information in their own comment papers;
  • successfully seeking and analyzing specialized literature;
  • embodying the obtained information into their own ideas and arguments.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Contents, course description
​
Understanding consumers is the key to a successful marketing strategy. Unfortunately, however, the mind of the consumer is not always easy to understand. This course provides an overview of theories that best explain how consumers arrive at their judgments and decisions. The course will review relevant theories from economics and psychology that provide a foundation for behavioural marketing. Consumer behaviour varies greatly depending on a range of factors. For instance, consumers’ judgments and decisions are influenced by the market environment (e.g., retail vs. online), the type of consumer (e.g., older vs. younger), and the type of product (e.g., hedonic vs. utilitarian goods), just to name a few. Although it is impossible to fully grasp and predict this behaviour, consumer researchers have created a body of knowledge that allows us to achieve at least a basic understanding of consumer needs, wants, decisions and actions. This course will provide a structured overview of this body of knowledge. In the first part of the course, students will be provided with an introduction to the psychology of perception, information processing, emotions and decision-making. The second part of the course will elaborate on the influences of the social environment, culture and situational factors on consumer behaviour. Additionally, the second part of this course will apply these theories and principles to real-world marketing problems.
Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives

1.    Provide you with a foundation in the theories, models, and other tools used by academic and industry marketers for understanding the determinants of consumer behavior.
2.    Provide you with general ideas about how to influence consumers, and about how you as a consumer are influenced by others (including marketers).
3.    Prepare you to write a master thesis on the topic of consumer behavior.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud This course uses a multi-dimension perspective to explain and apply the consumers’ behavioural elements. Ultimately therefore, the benefit of this course is that students (future marketeers) will be able to identify and analyse how consumer behaviour works in practice, offering students the tools to apply this knowledge to their own future marketing practice.

This course starts with the historical context of consumption, it assesses how this process works for individual consumers and it identifies and discusses the consumers’ decision-making processes, very much touching several behavioural study areas in psychology as well. 

For marketeers, it is critically important to appraise how both current and future buyers respond to the products and services that are offered to them and to use this insight to successfully offer products and services to buyers and consumers. We will assess the past, current and future trends in consumer behaviour.

Obviously, it is necessary that marketeers learn how to study the behaviour of their (potential) buyers before they can apply their findings and insights to help optimize the design of their products and services and thus generate the necessary profit for their firms.

  Leerdoelen After this consumer behaviour course, you will be able:
  • To evaluate past, current and future trends as well as consumer behaviour developments.
  • To identify how behavioural insight thinking impacts on consumer behaviour.
  • To identify the decision-making process stages of consumer shopping behaviour.
  • To explain how behavioural, cognitive and social learning impacts on consumer behaviour. 
  • To explain the perceptual process, from exposure to stimuli to consumer response.
  • To assess what attitude theory is and how this theory is used in consumer marketing. 
  • To analyse how personality, self and psychographics explain the consumer’s behaviour. 
  • To explain the role of group influence mechanisms on consumer behaviour.
  • To appraise how buyer behaviour relates to segments, differentiation and distinctiveness.
  • To assess and compare individual (age/knowledge/income) and external (socio-cultural /geographic/demographic/technological) factors that influence consumer behaviour. 
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Because of the online character of this year's lessons, clear paragraphs with clear subject titles have been added to the class presentations of the 7 lessons. Furthermore, since the length of the online individual Remindo written exams has been reduced from 3 hours to 2 hours, the number of exam questions as well as the content of the exam questions has been adjusted to compensate for that length.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud The goal of this course is to provide students with a proper understanding of consumption from the academic perspectives of the homo economicus, homo sociologicus, and homo aestheticus. Using this multi-disciplinary perspective, consumption will be addressed as a socially embedded practice where aspects of freedom and individual choice are to be considered in the light of the opportunities for consumption offered by a socio-historically specific context. This implies that students develop an understanding of the causes and consequences of consumption (both material and cultural) at both the micro-level (e.g., identity, routines, meaning-making) and the macro-level (e.g., sustainability, politics, citizenship). Having been offered a solid theoretical foundation on consumption, students will apply theoretical insights to actual consumption practices by conducting interviews on informants’ consumption practices. In addition, they will keep and present a one-week diary of their consumption and explore to what extent the theories offered apply to themselves, explicitly linking micro- and macro-levels of analysis so as to grasp the complex links between consumer behaviour on the one hand and its causes and consequences at the level of society.
  Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of: 
  • The main theories and concepts, including a critical appraisal of their historical emergence, regarding consumption and consumer culture
  • The consumer research traditions within economics and the social sciences
  • Various definitions of consumption
Students have developed skills to:
  • Apply theoretical concepts regarding consumption and consumer culture to empirical observations / their own lives
  • Report and reflect on their findings in oral and written form

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description

In this course, students will familiarize themselves with the main marketing research approaches for understanding consumer behavior. Students will acquire knowledge on: (1) how to accurately measure and analyze consumers’ preferences, attitudes and choices, and (2) how marketing variables (such as product benefits, assortments, advertisements and retail environments) affect consumer behavior. The course introduces the main methods for analyzing consumer behavior (e.g. structured and unstructured observations, experiments and survey research), and focuses on the design and analysis of experiments and surveys. Leerdoelen Learning Objectives

•    Understand the main research methods used to study consumer behavior
•    Analyze consumer research data, collected in experiments and in surveys
•    Interpret and make recommendations based on the results of the consumer research

course_title: Consumer Perceptions of Corporate Social Responsibility
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud A growing number of companies have started to recognize the value of sustainable business practices, and have adopted a pro-active search for opportunities to improve their societal and environmental impacts. These socially responsible practices can lead to a range of shared benefits for the company and for society. Despite these mutual benefits, it can be challenging for companies to promote their CSR activities. On the one hand, it is important for companies to communicate about their CSR performance in order to acquire potential reputational benefits. Moreover, consumers increasingly demand transparency from companies about their business conduct. On the other hand, consumers do not always respond positively to CSR information of companies. Consumers can be sceptical about the credibility of corporate claims about their involvement in CSR. Thus, even though companies might have sincere motives for their sustainability initiatives, the promotion of these initiatives can backfire due to suspicions of corporate greenwashing. Topics that are discussed in this course include the drivers of consumers’ preference for socially responsible companies, how CSR communication is evaluated by consumers, perceptions of sincerity of corporate motives to invest in CSR, and the role of new media in CSR communication. 
  Leerdoelen Students will gain knowledge and understanding of:
  • Theoretical approaches, concepts and perspectives in the field of Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) communication;
  • The challenges of communicating CSR initiatives; 
  • Consumer attitudes, motives and intentions regarding CSR.
 
Students will develop the skills to:
  • Systematically analyse and critically reflect on theoretical and practical issues in CSR communication;
  • Apply theoretical knowledge to and construct arguments about CSR-related communication strategies and issues.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud In modern society, identity is increasingly shaped and defined by what we buy, brands we wear, products we use, and consumer loyalties we claim. Perhaps as a consequence, in the past several decades consumer studies have grown in importance for sociological research. Accordingly, this course examines the connection between consumption and identity.  We begin by exploring contemporary theories of consumption, including ideas on rationalization and taste distinctions.  We then turn to consumption’s role in mediating the modern tension between establishing individual identity and community membership. We next address the possible dangers of using commodities of the culture industry to help shape our societies and ourselves. To what degree does the culture industry determine consumption practices and understandings? To address this question, we first examine the other side of consumption, supply, and how cultural producers and gatekeepers determine what products to offer. Once consumers attain these products, are they active or passive—i.e., how do they use, change, or reject commercial goods? Finally, we end the course by examining consumption’s role in social mobilization, including protest, to effect change.

  Leerdoelen Students will be able to identify the major issues within consumption studies and address those issues through a foundation of sociological theory and empirical research. Students will also be able to link concepts considered in class and the literature to the broader social context and their own social realities and consumption practices.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud In recent decades, cultural sociology has been one of the fastest growing areas of sociological study. Some have even argued that contemporary sociology has been witnessing a ‘cultural turn’ – making culture (‘meaning-making’) a central aspect of sociological inquiry in many different areas such as politics, economy, the state, etc. This course addresses major themes and theories in cultural sociology by discerning three ideal typical approaches:
 
  1. culture as cognitive structure approach, which studies the way in which cultural codes, schemas, narratives and texts constrain and enable the possible range and arrangement of meanings;
  2. culture in action approach, which focuses on the practical ways in which culture is reflexively used and set to work to solve everyday problems;
  3. production of culture approach, which focuses on how the content of culture (in the more restricted sense) is affected by its production, distribution and consumption.
 
We will study exemplary works from all three contemporary approaches in cultural sociology, and, furthermore, focus on work that integrates key ideas from these different approaches into the study of making meaning in various cultural genres such as music, literature, fashion and sports. Finally, we will zoom in on how gender, race/ethnicity and nationality affect meaning-making, and how each of the three abovementioned approaches has studied such questions differently. In this course students will develop and expand their knowledge of the sociological perspective on the arts and culture in the broad sense. They will be able to distinguish three contemporary theoretical approaches in cultural sociology (culture as cognitive structure, culture in action and production of culture) and identify these approaches in recent sociological research.

course_title: Contemporary Capitalism and Governance : Neo Liberalism and Beyond
college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
lecturers: ['dr. A Chhachhi', 'dr. CH Biekart', 'dr. HM Hintjens', 'dr. JD Handmaker', 'dr. NYT Shehada', 'dr. S Heumann', 'dr. S Mullassery Sathiamma', 'dr. SMS Jayasundara - Smits', 'mr.dr. DJE Misiedjan', 'prof.dr. RA Icaza Garza', 'prof.dr.ir. DJM Hilhorst', 'prof.mr.dr. CJM Arts']

college: Erasmus University College
lecturers: ['dr. CDC van der Veeke', 'JP Baan, BA']
text:
Inhoud

Ever since the advent of the 20th century, political philosophers have felt the need to philosophically legitimise the notion of a ‘liberal representative democracy’. In response, to both abstract thought and material history, many thinkers have tried to criticise liberal democracy’s basic premises; and conceptually restructure thinking about politics at large. This process is still going on, as can be seen in the writings of many contemporary political thinkers. In this course we focus on several key debates – and bones of contention – on liberal democracies in contemporary political theory and political philosophy. Central concepts include: justice, popular sovereignty, legitimacy, deliberative democracy, antagonism, hegemony and populism. These concepts will be discussed in reference to thinkers as diverse as Carl Schmitt, John Rawls, Jürgen Habermas, and Bonnie Honig.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
Erasmus School of Economics
Erasmus School of Law
text:
Inhoud Practitioners not only need to have an in-depth knowledge of contract law but are also often involved in drafting commercial contracts. The course Contract Drafting deals with techniques of international contract drafting from the perspective of comparative contract law. It builds on the activities of the International Contract Working Group chaired by Professor De Ly, which has been analysing contract clauses for the past thirty years leading to many publications. The course will cover boiler plate and tailor-made clauses from the contract formation point to the termination of the contract including letters of intent, merger clauses, force majeure and hardship clauses, exemption and penalty clauses, termination and post termination clauses, assignment clauses and dispute settlement clauses. Clauses used in practice, both pathological and model clauses, will be used as illustrations. The course is taught on the basis of the compulsory reading materials, case law materials and practical cases.
  Leerdoelen Familiarize students with drafting of various contract clauses from an international and comparative perspective against a background of law and business.

college: Erasmus MC Academie
Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
The role of the financial controller is changing in ways that mirror those of the broader finance function. Rather than serving as a rear-view mirror that only provides information about historical performance, the financial controller increasingly participate in the analysis and formulation of solutions to higher value-added, strategic issues. Reliance on forward-looking techniques tools allows the finance function to anticipate the future needs of the company to drive appropriate action, improve the current operating results and eventually maximize the bottom line.

The dynamic and integrative role of the controller function in business corporations is the focus of this course. Classes cover the principles underlying planning and control decisions in functional and divisional organizations, as well the design and consequences of responsibility accounting and performance measurement systems under various market conditions. The course also extends to financial controller’s roles in budgeting, strategic planning, pricing, risk management, corporate finance and investment related decision making.
 
The course is structured in lectures and tutorials. During the lecture part, the respective topics of each session are introduced and discussed. The emphasis in the tutorials is given to the preparation for CMA (Certified Management Accountant) Exam questions. Overall, by linking together financial management techniques and analytical business skills, the course aims at preparing students to manage the entire spectrum of responsibilities expected by financial professionals Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
 
At the end of this course students are able to:
•    Describe the characteristics of management planning and control in functional and divisional organizations
•    Describe responsibility accounting and the role of efficiency and effectiveness in performance measurement.
•    Describe controllers' roles in cost management, strategic planning, programming, and budgeting, pricing, corporate finance and investment related decision making.
•    Apply methods and techniques essential for working as a corporate Controller.
•    Assess Pros and Cons of different methods in cost management, strategic planning, budgeting & pricing.

college: Erasmus University College
lecturers: ['AA Petruchenya', 'dr. CWA van Wijnbergen', 'dr. G Domini', 'S Hoxha, MSc', 'TB Kik']
text:
Inhoud

 

This course aims to develop a basic understanding of economic behaviour. We will do so by examining the intuitions and the real world underpinning of the ‘maths and the models’ of economics. The focus is on teaching economic tools and concepts by addressing relevant questions, such as the causes and consequences of the financial crisis or economic inequality. Topics that will be discussed include individual decision making (‘how do people divide their time between leisure and working?’), firm decision-making (‘how do firms decide how much to produce?’), market mechanisms (‘how is decided what price we pay for our products?’), the financial world (‘how is money created?’), and how an economy can be described and measured, at an aggregate level.

The course is empirically motivated and illustrated. Based on facts from history, experiments and data, students will learn how economic insights and models can be used to understand the real world. The course will introduce you to key concepts in economic theory and economic reasoning on the basis of the curriculum developed by the core economics project.


  Leerdoelen After following this course, you will have an understanding of:
  • what the science of economics is about;
  • the tools and concepts of economics;
  • the characteristics of the different recent economic epochs and their effect on the economy and the science of economics;
  • choices people make given the opportunities available;
  • the working and the limits of markets
  • the elements of the aggregate economy and how government policies can affect these elements;
  • the role banks play in the economy.

college: Erasmus School of Law

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. R Mittal', 'dr. S Nguyen', 'dr. Y Wang']
text:
Inhoud This course provides an overview of the approaches, perspectives, and dimensions of corporate communication in an environment where branding and reputation are paramount. Students will learn about the functions, practices, challenges and opportunities of corporate communication in an international and social-mediated context.. Students will understand and critique the various roles that communication plays in the internal and external relations of organizations through a mix of case studies, course readings, and perspectives from the field.

Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 75. IBCoM students take priority over other students. Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • Multiple aspects of corporate communication including: public relations, branding, reputation, crisis communication, social responsibility, and stakeholder management
  • The challenges and developments in the field of scholarship and practice (e.g., with new media technologies, globalization)
  • The professional practice of corporate communication in an international context
Students have developed the skills to:
  • Analyze and critically reflect upon corporate communication practices using concepts and theories covered in this course
  • Apply disciplinary knowledge to contemporary cases and formulate and report arguments about corporate communication issues

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Corporate communication plays an important role in how organizations are perceived by both internal and external stakeholders. This course explores media and public relations, employee communications and crisis communication and looks at how they should be managed to build and maintain a strong reputation. Students will understand and critique the various roles that communication plays in the internal and external relations of organizations.

Note: The maximum number of participants is 60
  Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • Multiple aspects of corporate communication including: advertising, marketing, public relations, internal communication and new media
  • The components of a comprehensive corporate communication plan
  • The role of research methods in corporate communication.
  • The work of professional corporate communicators including ethics and legal standards
Students have developed the skills to:
  • Analyze and critically reflect upon corporate communications practices using the concepts and theories covered in this course.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
​
In today’s dynamic and continuously changing business environment, entrepreneurship is an essential and indispensable element in the success of many organizations. Corporate entrepreneurship (or intrapreneurship) refers to activities involved in creating and exploiting new resource combinations in the context of existing corporations. Although many business books purport to teach top management how to create a culture that nurtures visionaries like Sergey Brin (Google) and Mark Zuckerberg (Facebook), the ability to think and act entrepreneurially and engage in ongoing processes of creativity often fails because established organizations present hostile environments for entrepreneurial ideas. This core course focuses primarily on organizational and managerial efforts aimed at the identification, development and exploitation of entrepreneurial ideas, the management of new product or process developments, and on effective new venture management in the context of large corporations. Topics include ways how organizations can stimulate corporate entrepreneurship, entrepreneurial action, work contexts, exploration and exploitation.

The grading of the course will be based on two components. First, theoretical knowledge and practical knowledge based on lectures will be tested by a written test (60% of the course grade). Second, you will operate in a team of students to analyze an entrepreneurial challenge in a corporate organization. As a team you develop an advisory report on how the organization can become entrepreneurial (40% of the course grade).  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives

The main objective of the core course is to develop an awareness and understanding of the range, scope, and complexity of the issues related to the creation of an organizational environment that is supportive of entrepreneurial endeavors as well as to gain insight concerning the effective implementation of technological and organizational new business development in a corporate setting.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud This course is an extensive introduction to the basic tools, techniques and theories that are necessary to understand the financial decision-making in the modern corporation. The themes we deal with in this course are particularly relevant for business decision-making in areas as whether or not to invest in a project, how to finance an investment, and how to deal with uncertainty.
 
Corporate finance can be seen as supportive to other fields such as strategy or marketing; often in these fields the business decisions are formulated (e.g., in what markets or products should we invest), whereas in corporate finance we evaluate these choices and analyse how to fund them best.
  Leerdoelen Following this course, you should be able to:
 
  • Analyse the financing decisions of companies.
  • Calculate the value of a company that is financed with equity and debt based on an analysis of the relevant cash flows.
  • Analyse the impact of real options and dividend policy on the value of companies.
  • Apply complex financial instruments such as futures, options, (convertible) bonds and warrants.
  • Apply pricing models of complex financial instruments such as futures, options, (convertible) bonds and warrants.
  • Apply key international finance models such as Purchasing Power Parity, international Fisher effect and covered and uncovered interest parity.
  • In addition to these main topics, we deal with some specific topics.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Course content, description

Corporate Finance deals with two broad and interrelated themes: how to value businesses and corporate investment opportunities; and how to finance corporate investment and activities. 

The main topic of the course is on financing and financial policy covering the trade-of theory of capital structure, tax benefits, signalling models, as well as key features of the issuance process for certain kinds of debt and equity. Other topics include working capital management, corporate governance, and risk management.

Entry requirements or required background knowledge
No formal entry requirements, but a sound undergraduate knowledge of corporate finance is strongly recommended. Leerdoelen Learning Objectives

At the end of this course students will be able to:
•    Describe and understand the various types of financial instruments used to finance firms, from an economic, financial and practical point of view
•    Suggest a suitable capital structure for a firm
•    Critically evaluate the effects of agency and information problems on the firms’ financial policies and capital structure
•    Understand the role of corporate governance and risk management and its effect on firm value
•    Understand the role of stakeholders in corporate decision-making vis-à-vis financial considerations
•    Read, discuss and report academic journal articles in corporate finance

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Contents, course description
​
Finance deals with topics that are particularly relevant for business decision-making such as whether or not to invest in a project, how to finance an investment, and how to deal with uncertainty. 
This course deals with the modern fundamentals of finance and describes how investment opportunities are valued in financial markets. The most important concepts in this course are the net present value, capital budgeting, the risk-return relationship, and the efficient market hypothesis. We will use these concepts to address one central question: How should a manager of a firm make investment decisions?

Leerdoelen Learning Objectives

At the end of this course, student should be able to: 
•    Understand the concept of time value of money and be able to value a stream of cash flows 
•    Valuate assets with the net present value and other valuation methods 
•    Make investment decisions by applying appropriate decision rules
•    Select amongst investment opportunities by comparing risk and return, as well as by comparing any alternatives available 
•    Understand the cost of capital and firm value 
•    Formulate the implications of the efficient market hypothesis on the prices of equity

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
 
This course is an extensive introduction to the basic tools, techniques and theories that are necessary to understand the financial decision-making in the modern corporation. The themes we deal with in this course are particularly relevant for business decision-making and will dive into questions such as: whether or not to invest in a project, how to finance an investment, and how to deal with uncertainty.

Corporate finance can be seen as supportive to other fields such as strategy or marketing; often in these fields the business decisions are formulated (e.g., in what markets or products should we invest), whereas in corporate finance we evaluate these choices and analyse how to fund them best.
 
Leerdoelen
After following this course, students will be able to
​
  • Analyse the connection between risk of an asset and expected return of an asset and be able to apply the CAPM correctly.

  • Calculate and interpret the most important metrics used in short-term financing.

college: Erasmus University College
lecturers: ['A Tase', 'dr. MBJ Schauten', 'dr. Z Sharif', 'TB Kik']
text:
Inhoud
Finance appears to be at the nexus of recent political developments, not least due to its effect on the recent financial crisis. Corporate finance is much more than a collection of equations, matrices and models. Corporate finance is a set of first principles that govern how we run businesses. This is an introductory finance course that addresses the key decisions and issues faced by senior financial officers in corporations and the analytical frameworks and approaches that are helpful in addressing these issues. This course is an extensive introduction to the basic tools, techniques and theories that are necessary to understand the financial decision-making in the modern corporation. At the end of this course you will be able to apply Corporate Finance to unstructured real-life problems, get the bigger picture before you press the button, and be able to make numerical exercises as well as understanding the theories/models behind them.
Leerdoelen
After successfully completing the course you will be able to:
  • explain the implications of the model of Hirshleifer and the separation theorem of Fisher;
  • apply the net present value method and other investment selection criteria;
  • determine the value of financial assets such as shares and bonds;
  • combine individual financial assets into a portfolio of financial assets;
  • explain the difference between profits and cash flows;
  • explain the portfolio theory and the Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM);
  • apply the CAPM to set a discount rate;
  • explain the consequences of an efficient market for the investors in financial assets;
  • explain the consequences of an efficient market for the investors in real assets;
  • determine the net present value of a merger.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud
The main topics to be covered in this course include:
  • Capital budgeting
  • Firm valuation
  • Event study
  • Payout policy
  • Financing with equity and debt
  • Mergers & acquisitions
     
Leerdoelen - Become familiar with major topics in Corporate Finance such as valuation, capital structure policy, payout policy, equity and debt financing, and mergers and acquisitions.
- Understand and apply three key valuation techniques.
- DCF-WACC (Discounted Cash Flow-Weighted Average Cost of Capital .
- APV (Adjusted Prese- Learn to compute the cost of capital and estimate its components by relying on the Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM).
