college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

The course Financial Management runs across two blocks. We start in block 2, where mainly topics related to accounting are discussed. Accounting is referred to as the language of business, because it is widely used to reflect all types of business activities. This course provides insights in core concepts in accounting. We discuss the various ways in which financial and non-financial information can be compiled, and how this information is communicated to decision makers. In general, we distinguish between financial accounting and management accounting.

Financial accounting deals with the primary financial statements – balance sheet, income statement and cash flow statement – and is designed primarily to assist external stakeholders, such as investors and creditors, in deciding where or whether to invest their money. What information financial statements present, how it is linked and how to interpret this information is discussed.

Management accounting emphasizes the use of accounting information for internal planning and control purposes. Any organization’s long-term competitive success is critically dependent on (1) the quality of accounting information about its products, services, processes, suppliers, and customers, (2) taking rational decisions based on accounting information, and (3) motivating its employees and controlling its performance consistent with that information. Important topics include cost accounting, cost-volume-profit analysis, budgeting, responsibility accounting, relevant costing and decision-making.

In block 3 topics in finance are discussed. Finance deals with topics that are particularly relevant for business decision-making in areas as whether or not to invest in a project, how to finance an investment, and how to deal with uncertainty. Finance is associated with decision-making related to external stakeholders.

This part of the course deals with the modern fundamentals of finance and describes how investment opportunities are valued in financial markets. The most important concepts in this course are the net present value, capital budgeting, the risk-return relationship, the efficient market hypothesis, and capital structure. We will use these concepts for addressing two central questions throughout this course:

  1. How should a financial manager of a firm take investments decisions?
  2. How should the investments be financed?

This course is worth 6 EC and runs in block 2 and 3.

Leerdoelen
At the end of this course the student should be able to:
  • Understand the concept of time value of money and be able to value a stream of cash flows
  • Valuate assets by means of both the net present value and multiples
  • Select amongst investment opportunities by comparing risk and return, as well as by comparing any alternatives available
  • Relate investment decisions to capital budgeting and capital structure
  • Understand the implications of capital structure for cost of capital and firm value
  • Formulate the implications of the efficient market hypothesis on the prices of equity
     
  • Interpret and analyze a balance sheet and income statement;
  • Execute a cash flow analysis;
  • Implement basic financial analysis;
  • Use various cost price calculation methods;
  • Identify different cost types and relevant costs for specific business decisions;
  • Choose the economically optimal alternative course of action;
  • List the behavioral effects of performance evaluations based on financial indicators;
  • Understand the link between financial and management accounting.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['AG Andrei, MSc', 'dr. P Darnihamedani', 'prof.dr. J van Oosterhout']
text:
Inhoud

This course discusses the corporate governance challenges of various kinds of private enterprise organization, as well as the measures and practices that can be used to meet these challenges. After introducing a general framework, we will look at the corporate governance challenges of publicly listed firms, family firms, (professional) partnerships, State owned enterprises, and non-profit organizations, such as philanthropies, for example. Although we focus mainly on the role and interests of owners in these firms, we will also discuss how corporate governance affects the interests of other stakeholders, such as employees, customers, creditors or society at large.

Corporate governance is about the ownership, decision-making and accountability practices through which modern enterprise organizations develop and deploy their resources in order to create value and secure a sustainable future while taking into account the business context at large. Within publicly listed firms, for example, executives make the bulk of everyday business decisions, while highly dispersed and therefore mostly uninvolved shareholders and other stakeholders face their economic consequences.

A striking fact about modern economic organization, however, is that there are not only publicly listed firms, but many different forms of enterprise organization, such as: (professional) partnerships, state-owned enterprises, cooperatives, family firms, and non-profit organizations such as philanthropies. Each of these organizational forms faces its own distinctive corporate governance challenges and will need to develop equally specific practices to meet these challenges.

In this course, we will survey and discuss various forms of enterprise organization in order to unveil the specific corporate governance challenges that they face. As modern capitalism is predicated on the private ownership of the means of production, we focus (but not exclusively) on the role of owners of these organizations but we will also take into account the role of societal stakeholders.


This course is worth 4 EC.

 
Leerdoelen
  • Understand what corporate governance is and how it matters in business
  • Understand the role of ownership in firms and how it matters in corporate governance more specifically
  • Think strategically about different ways to meet the specific corporate governance challenges that come with   different types of ownership of the firm
  • Think strategically about different ways in which firms can shape and manage their relationship with their stakeholders
  • Think strategically about different ways in which firms can develop and maintain their institutional license to operate
  • Ultimately to think strategically about how to align the ownership and governance practices of a firm with its core activities, critical resources and resource dependencies, its current and future business model, and its societal license to operate

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['mr. O Oost', 'mr. T Spronk', 'mr.drs. ACW Pijls', 'mr.drs. BAJ van Leent', 'mr.drs. KH Boonzaaijer']
text:
Inhoud Het vak Corporate Governance en Corporate Litigation richt zich op de interne structuur van N.V.’s en B.V.’s, op de aansprakelijkheidspositie van functionarissen van N.V.’s en B.V.’s en op juridische procedures rondom vennootschappen. Tot de vragen en aspecten die aan de orde komen tijdens dit vak behoren de volgende.
  • Wat is corporate governance? Wat is corporate litigation?
  • Is er een verschil tussen corporate governance en corporate litigation in besloten vennootschappelijke verhoudingen en open verhoudingen (beursvennootschappen)?
  • Wat is het gevolg van toepasselijkheid van de structuurregeling op de interne verhoudingen?
  • Wat is de invloed van concernvorming op de interne verhoudingen?
  • Welke (juridische) regels beheersen de interne verhoudingen in vennootschappen?
  • Wat zijn de taken en bevoegdheden van het bestuur? Wat is het belang van bestuursautonomie? Hoe wordt bestuursautonomie beschermd? Wanneer is sprake van onbehoorlijk bestuur; wanneer van wanbeleid?
  • Wat zijn de verschillen en overeenkomsten tussen een dualistisch bestuursmodel (two tier board) en een monistisch bestuursmodel (one tier board)?
  • Hoe functioneert de raad van commissarissen? Wat is het belang van onafhankelijkheid van commissarissen?
  • Hoe functioneert de algemene vergadering? Zijn er verschillen tussen een vennootschap met een verspreid aandelenbezit of met een beperkt aantal (groot)aandeelhouders?
  • Welke rechten en plichten hebben aandeelhouders? Hoe is de bescherming van minderheidsaandeelhouders geregeld? Hoe kunnen zij hun positie in een juridische procedure beschermen?
  • Hoe kunnen vennootschappen zich beschermen tegen activistische aandeelhouders?
  • Op welke wijze komen de hiervoor vermelde vragen aan de orde in juridische procedures op het terrein van het ondernemingsrecht?
  • Wat zijn de vennootschapsrechtelijke en procesrechtelijke aspecten die verband houden met geschillen binnen/rond ondernemingen?
  • Waar en hoe zijn de enquêteprocedure, de geschillenregelingprocedure, de uitkoopprocedure, relevante aansprakelijkheidsprocedures en de procedure voor aantasting van besluiten van de vennootschap geregeld?
  • Het vak besteedt daar waar nuttig/mogelijk aandacht aan rechtsvergelijkende aspecten.
Leerdoelen Na voltooiing van dit vak kunnen studenten:
  • de onderwerpen die behoren tot corporate governance benoemen, beoordelen of in een concreet geval sprake is van goede corporate governance en daarbij de eigen kenmerken van open en besloten verhoudingen betrekken;
  • de interne verhoudingen en de verantwoordelijkheid en aansprakelijkheid van verschillende actoren in kapitaalvennootschappen beschrijven en casusposities hierover oplossen;
  • beoordelen of een vennootschap valt onder het (verzwakt) structuurregime;
  • de verschillende soorten beschermingsconstructies analyseren en beoordelen en casusposities hierover oplossen;
  • Europese en internationale perspectieven betrekken bij onderwerpen die behoren tot corporate governance;
  • economische en psychologische aspecten en inzichten betrekken bij onderwerpen die behoren tot corporate governance;
  • de verschillende ondernemingsrechtelijke procedures onderscheiden, hun toepassingsgebied benoemen, voor een bepaald geschil de meest geschikte procedurele rechtsgang kiezen en regels van bewijsrecht benoemen voor deze procedure;
  • zelfstandig nationale en internationale wetenschappelijke teksten over onderwerpen die behoren tot corporate governance en corporate litigation analyseren, beoordelen en daarop kritisch reflecteren;
  • in samenwerking met medestudenten analyseren, aan de hand van toepasselijke wettelijke, statutaire en contractuele regels en regels die voortvloeien uit corporate governance codes, wat de interne structuur van een concrete vennootschap is en welke sterke en zwakke punten aan die interne structuur zijn verbonden uit het oogpunt van een goede corporate governance.

college: Erasmus School of Law
text:
Inhoud Economic efficiency may be undermined by misallocation of financial resources. This course discusses corporate law and financial regulation from the perspective of the correction of financial markets failure. The course focuses on the various legal, contractual and extra-legal mechanisms available to protect (minority) shareholders and other stakeholders from the self-serving behavior of managers and of controlling shareholders. Moreover, the course addresses the problem of financial distress and its consequences for the financing of private and public enterprises, as well as for financial stability.
 
This course is open for EMLE students only.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud Corporate Innovation and Venture Capital: Corporate entrepreneurship refers to the spawning of or pioneering of new businesses within established firms building on their strengths -- an increasingly important process in the organization of corporate research and management of innovation -- and distinct from the study of entrepreneurship (or the founding of new firms).

This course will explore changes in managing innovation in large established companies and emerging models of corporate entrepreneurship. The course will study formal theories of intrapraneurship that have emerged in the last decade and explore the phenomenon through case studies of particular firms, case studies of particular inventions, and also industry studies of how corporate entrepreneurship (and its failure) determine industry dynamics. We will also cover empirical studies of the tradeoff between entrepreneurship and intrapraneurship.
  Leerdoelen
  • To describe and explain several theories of corporate entrepreneurship.
  • To develop a framework for studying alternative forms of corporate entrepreneurship.
  • To examine critically the challenges for large established firms in organizing and managing corporate entrepreneurshi pprograms research in an established firm.
  • To propose ways for public policy to facilitate corproate entrepreneurship programs.
  • To analyze and calculate the conditions under which entrepreneurs prefer corporate entrepreneurship relative to pure entrepreneurship.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The course material has remained the same but changes are made to accommodate teaching and testing online.

course_title: Corporate Political Strategies and Non-market Competition
college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Course overview
​
This course addresses a variety of political and social (i.e. non-market) boundaries, which, when considered along with market boundaries, help us understand why some firms thrive and others struggle. The non-market is a sometimes-neglected arena, which can severely limit or enable firms in doing business and influence their strategy. Eventually non-market boundaries can affect firm success, while they are particularly challenging to navigate since non-market actors differ in their motives, objectives and tactics relative to conventional market actors. Overall, the non-market opens up questions calling for strategic answers: How do firms incorporate interests of non-market actors, who are not (primarily) concerned about wealth maximization? How do firms draw the line between and manage their ‘duty’ to their constituents (i.e. non-market strategy) and their obligation to shareholders (i.e. market strategy)? What are the benefits and perils of corporate political and social engagement? Ultimately, is the management of non-market interests a means to an end, or an end in itself? In this elective, we will address these questions and discuss how firms are affected, and how they can themselves affect their non-market context. This will help us understand non-market strategy, why some firms thrive, while similar ones may struggle in the politically and socially colored market. Leerdoelen Learning Objectives

At the end of the course, students will be able to:
•    Understand firm strategy in the context of firm interactions with non-market stakeholders who do not have profit maximization as their primary objective.
•    Discuss different non-market strategies, as well as the integration of market and non-market strategies.
•    Analyze key issues faced by firms in the non-market context.
•    Evaluate firms’ non-market issues with strategic tools and methods.
•    Devise a strategic plan to address a firm’s issues in the non-market.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents
Corporate Restructuring can broadly be understood as the slicing, dicing and recombining of businesses within and across organizational boundaries. It comes in various forms including spin-offs, sell-offs, equity carve-outs, mergers and acquisitions, or asset swaps, which are carried out in isolation, or as part of a broader restructuring program.
 
Corporate restructuring activities can represent attempts to rescue a firm from the verge of bankruptcy, responses to unexpected macroeconomic occurrences, or opportunity-driven projects initiated by activist investors, analysts or corporate-level decision makers. Planning and implementing corporate restructuring moves are associated with a high level of uncertainty and complexity. Not only do they frequently fail to reach their intended objectives, they also have far-reaching implications for various stakeholders.
 
In this course we explore and analyze corporate restructuring from different angles: We review recent research findings and adopt different theoretical lenses to gain a comprehensive understanding of the drivers, characteristics, and implications of corporate restructuring activities from the perspective of various market participants.
Analyzing specific restructuring cases, we shed light on the managerial challenges of planning and implementing restructuring activities.
 
Format
The teaching methods used in this course consist of lectures, cases, group discussions, and team assignments. Students are expected to come to each session well-prepared by having read the required readings for the session. Attendance is mandatory.
  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
  • To gain a theoretical understanding of the drivers and implications of different types of corporate restructuring and an overview of the most relevant research findings on the topic.
  • To understand the managerial challenges associated with the initiation and implementation of restructuring activities.
  • To develop skills to analyze and evaluate all factors and actors relevant to corporate restructuring situations.
  • To gain a nuanced view on corporate restructuring as a societal phenomenon, driven by different fads, pressures and ideologies, with far-reaching implications for many stakeholders.

course_title: Corporate Social Investment as a force for positive social change
college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Contents, course description

The statistics are very clear and pressing: if we want to reach the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), we still have a funding gap of a $ 2.5 trillion annually.  We therefore need to find further investments in the SDGs and ways to scale the impact as merely financial resources will not suffice. An increasingly relevant player in this field are Corporate Social Investors; e.g. corporate foundations, corporate social impact funds and corporate social accelerators. 

Why? Because these Corporate Social Investors operate in between the business and the ultimate beneficiary and are in the unique situation to leverage corporate resources such as financial means, products, services, technology and the corporate network for the public good. As companies realize that by only pursuing commercial strategies, our wicked problems will not be resolved, an increasing number of companies are implementing non-commercial strategies to contribute to society.

Indeed, Corporate Social Investors are formalized in a separate legal structure to safeguard that they put social impact at the core of their activities rather than the financial return. As such, CSIs are aimed at “transforming patterns of thought, behaviour, social relationships, institutions, and social structure to generate beneficial outcomes for individuals, communities, organisations, society, and/or the environment beyond the benefits for the instigators of such transformation” (Stephan et al., 2016, p. 1252; italics added). 

The aim of this course is to introduce students with Corporate Social Investments where social impact is at the core of the activities, rather than the financial return. We will discuss why are companies pursuing this strategy and set up these organizational structures? What is the role of these Corporate Social Investors in society? What are their strategies? What can they do what the company cannot? And, how are these Corporate Social Investors being managed efficiently and effectively? 

The course has five modules: 
Module 1: Introduction and Corporate Social Investors in Europe
Module 2: Impact Only, Impact first or Finance First? 
Module 3: Governance and management
Module 4: Non-financial support
Module 5: Future models for Corporate Social Investors?

In each module, we have an (international) expert from the field. To give some examples, in 2020, we have European Venture Philanthropy Association, Ikea Social Entrepreneurship, Trafigura Foundation, Human Safety Net and Water Revolution Foundation. 

Leerdoelen Learning goals:
After attending the theoretical classes, the practical guestlectures, the debate and after completing the two assignments that this class will offer, the student will be able to:
•    understand why and how businesses choose for non-commercial strategies to create positive social change.
•    explain what the difference is between finance first (or only) and impact first (or only) strategies are and when to pursue one above the other. 
•    argue why corporate social investors are needed when companies implement their sustainability agenda (and/or adopt SDGs). 
•    apply various theories (mostly organizational behavior theories) around corporate social investment on contemporary managerial issues of corporate social investors.
•    defend an impact-first or impact only strategy that companies may seek in their sustainability portfolio.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud This seminar takes an in-depth look at the growing importance (and acceptance) of corporate social responsibility (CSR) as a key reputational asset for organizations of all types. At its crux, CSR is a conversation about the role(s) of business in society and signals a shift in management focus from shareholders to stakeholders. It is estimated that CSR contributes over 40 per cent to corporate reputation, and cognizant of the reputational impact of being socially (ir)responsible, leading organizations are making concerted efforts to do good and be good. Increasingly, firms are embedding CSR in their business strategy and corporate purpose, communicating CSR engagements, and encouraging employee engagement with CSR.
 
Although CSR now enjoys the status of being a ‘global’ phenomenon, it is, by no means, universal or unitary. Nor are its outcomes always positive.
The course will review the contemporary state of international CSR research from different theoretical lenses; examine intersections with corporate reputation and leadership; highlight the communication imperative for CSR; and reflect on the impact of new media developments on CSR reputation management.
  Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • The evolution, models, debates, and theories in international CSR scholarship
  • The multi-dimensional role of communication in CSR research and practice
  • The implications of CSR for reputation and leadership
Students have developed skills to:
  • Analyze the relevance of CSR in building corporate reputation.
  • Assess the contextual considerations in CSR strategy and practice
  • Analyze the opportunities and challenges in communicating CSR

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Course Overview

Over the past years, small firms and start-ups have started to play an increasingly important role in our economy. R&D spending by small firms has increased and many disruptive innovations have been conceived by new entrants to an industry, thereby posing a major threat to existing firms. In order to sustain their competitive advantage, it is important for large firms such as Shell, DSM, and KLM to tap into the knowledge of these start-ups and to invest in corporate venturing. Corporate venturing can be achieved in different ways, including: taking a minority position in outside businesses (corporate venture capital), building a new business as a stand-alone unit (spin-out), or building a new business inside the existing firm with a structure allowing for managerial autonomy and independence (corporate incubator or accelerator). This course will discuss strategies, organizational structures and implementation challenges of new ventures within an established corporation as well as options to leverage external partners outside the boundaries of the corporation within the process of new business development.
Leerdoelen
Learning objectives

By the end of the course, students should be able to:
Discuss the different forms of corporate venturing and how each of them advances corporate innovation
Identify key trends and organizational practices of corporate venturing
Describe the importance of corporate venturing and the various ways in which it can be organized and recognized within companies
Demonstrate a multidisciplinary view on corporate venturing and open innovation

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description

All over the world, firms are being disrupted by fast-moving, innovative startups such as Uber, AirBnB, Spotify and Snapchat. Startups are known for their innovative business models, exciting and promising ideas, and organizational agility. In contrast, large firms have an abundance of resources, scale advantages, power and experience (Weiblen & Chesbrough, 2015). Rather than simply competing, both large firms and startups have started to see the advantages of joining forces, allowing new innovations to emerge.
Through corporate venturing, the corporation may invest in a startup within or outside of the organizational domain (Sharma & Chrisman, 1999). However, despite their promising outlook, corporate venturing activities are often not successful for both the investor and the startup. Because of the potentially high risks and high rewards involved, corporate venturing has been compared to ‘swimming with sharks’. In this course at the intersection of strategy and entrepreneurship, we will therefore focus on both the benefits and challenges of managing a corporate venturing portfolio.

Format
This course aims to bridge the gap between academic literature and real-world situations. Therefore, guest lectures by corporate venturing managers from leading Dutch companies will complement the theoretical part of the course. In order to generate an atmosphere in which students learn through both individual study and class interaction, teaching methods will be varied and include a combination of lectures, class discussions and guest lectures.
 
Grading
The course does not contain an exam. Instead, the grading will consist of an individual assignment (60%) and group project (40%). Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
•    To understand how firms can manage corporate venturing.
•    To understand the effect of corporate venturing and corporate venture capital on value creation. How can firms use corporate venturing to spur their own businesses?
•    To understand the tensions and opportunities within a corporate venturing portfolio.
•    To learn how to mitigate some of the risks of corporate venturing.
•    To understand the role of corporate venturing in combination with alliances, mergers and acquisitions, and other external corporate development modes.
•    To apply this knowledge to a real-life situation.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud This course is an extensive introduction to the basic tools, techniques and theories that are necessary to understand the financial decision-making in the modern corporation. The themes we deal with in this course are particularly relevant for business decision-making and will dive into questions such as: whether or not to invest in a project, how to finance an investment, and how to deal with uncertainty.

Corporate finance can be seen as supportive to other fields such as strategy or marketing; often in these fields the business decisions are formulated (e.g., in what markets or products should we invest), whereas in corporate finance we evaluate these choices and analyse how to fund them best.
  Leerdoelen After following this course, students will be able to
  • Analyse the connection between risk of an asset and expected return of an asset and be able to apply the CAPM correctly.
  • Describe the different forms of market efficiency and explain their relevance for understanding stock price movements.
  • Analyse the financing decisions of companies.
  • Calculate the value of a company that is financed with equity and debt based on an analysis of the relevant cash flows.
  • Analyse the impact of dividend policy on the value of companies.
  • Apply complex financial instruments (futures and options, convertible bonds and warrants) in the context of risk management.
  • Apply pricing models of complex financial instruments such as futures, options, (convertible) bonds and warrants.
  • Describe and analyze the underlying mechanisms of short-term financing.
  • Calculate and interpret the most important metrics used in short-term financing.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Dit vak is een diepgaande introductie tot de basismiddelen, technieken en theorieën die nodig zijn om te begrijpen hoe binnen de onderneming financiële beslissingen worden genomen. Tijdens dit vak worden onderwerpen behandeld die vooral belangrijk zijn voor beslissingsdoeleinden voor bedrijven. Enkele voorbeelden zijn of er al dan niet in een bepaald project geïnvesteerd moet worden, hoe een investering gefinancierd dient te worden en hoe om te gaan met risico/onzekerheid.
 
Corporate Finance is een discipline die andere disciplines zoals strategie en marketing ondersteunt. In deze overige disciplines worden vaak vraagstukken gesteld zoals; in welke markten en producten dienen we te investeren? Corporate Finance ondersteunt dit door diverse keuzes te evalueren en te analyseren hoe deze keuzes het beste gefinancierd kunnen worden.
  Leerdoelen Na het volgen van dit vak, moet u in staat zijn tot:
  • Het analyseren van financiële beslissingen die ondernemingen maken.
  • Het berekenen van de waarde van ondernemingen die met eigen en/of vreemd vermogen zijn gefinancierd aan de hand van relevante kasstromen.
  • Het analyseren van de invloed van opties en dividendbeleid op de waarde van de onderneming.
  • Het toepassen van complexe financiële instrumenten zoals futures, opties, (converteerbare) obligaties en warrants.
  • Het toepassen van belangrijke financiële modellen zoals de koopkrachtpariteit, het internationale Fisher effect en (on)gedekte interest pariteit.
Het toepassen van een aantal overige topics die belangrijk zijn binnen corporate finance.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['AFM Hof', 'dr. CT Witte', 'prof.dr. J van Oosterhout']
text:
Inhoud

Corporate governance gaat over de ‘rules of the game’ waarbinnen moderne ondernemingsorganisaties hun middelen verkrijgen, ontwikkelen en inzetten om waarde te creëren voor de partijen die bij het bedrijf betrokken zijn. Binnen beursgenoteerde bedrijven nemen leidinggevenden het grootste deel van de dagelijkse zakelijke beslissingen, terwijl aandeelhouders die vaak niet betrokken zijn bij deze beslissingen, met de economische gevolgen worden geconfronteerd. Dit maakt dat de vraag welke corporate governance-praktijken (of mechanismen) kunnen worden ingezet om aandeelhouders te verzekeren dat leidinggevenden acties ondernemen die waarde voor aandeelhouderswaarde creëren, voor corporate governance voor dergelijke bedrijven centraal staat.


Opvallend aan de moderne economische organisatie is dat er naast beursgenoteerde bedrijven, ook andere vormen van organisatie voorkomen, zoals: familiebedrijven, (professionele) samenwerkingsverbanden, coöperaties en non-profitorganisaties. Elk van deze organisatievormen staat voor zijn eigen specifieke uitdagingen op het gebied van corporate governance en zal een reeks even specifieke corporate governance-structuren en praktijken moeten ontwikkelen om deze uitdagingen het hoofd te bieden.

In deze cursus zullen we verschillende vormen van bedrijfsorganisatie in verschillende stadia van hun levenscyclus analyseren om inzicht te krijgen in de specifieke corporate governance uitdagingen waarmee ze worden geconfronteerd. Aangezien het moderne kapitalisme is gebaseerd op het privé-eigendom van ondernemingen, zal onze analyse beginnen bij de rol van eigenaren in deze organisaties. Omdat het voortbestaan van de onderneming vaak ook kritisch afhankelijk is van de voortdurende steun van niet-aandeelhouders, zoals bijvoorbeeld medewerkers, leveranciers en klanten, zullen we ook de vraag onderzoeken hoe corporate governance de belangen van andere partijen kan behartigen. Zo zullen we analyseren hoe bedrijven hun 'maatschappelijke licentie om te opereren' kunnen ontwikkelen en veilig kunnen stellen om hun huidige (en toekomstige) bedrijfsmodellen te kunnen exploiteren.

In deze cursus gaat om het ontwikkelen van kennis en vaardigheden over een breed scala aan concepten, theorieën, uitdagingen, structuren en praktijken in de hedendaagse corporate governance. Door in elke sessie een andere strategische vraag te behandelen, wordt gestreefd naar het ontwikkelen van een strategische manier van denken over corporate governance.

Leerdoelen Na afronding van het vak is de student tot het volgende in staat:
  • Identificeren en begrijpen van theoretische concepten en kaders op het snijvlak van bedrijfsstrategie, bedrijfseigendom en corporate governance;
  • Integreren van de theoretische inzichten, conceptuele kaders en relevante empirische bewijzen die ten grondslag liggen aan de strategische eigendoms- en bestuurskeuzes van bedrijven;
  • In de praktijk toepassen van theoretische concepten en kaders met betrekking tot de ontwikkeling en implementatie van een corporate ownership en governance strategie voor bedrijven;
  • Ontwikkelen van een corporate ownership en governance strategie voor een bedrijf;
  • Analyseren van kansen en uitdagingen bij het ontwikkelen van strategische opties voor veranderingen in eigendom en bestuur in bedrijven;
  • Aantonen van het vermogen om in teamverband aan te werken, waarbij een basisniveau van bekwaamheid wordt getoond in het werken met hoogwaardige en onvolledige informatie op een effectieve en ethisch verantwoorde manier;
  • Strategisch nadenken over hoe eigendoms- en bestuurspraktijken kunnen worden afgestemd op de bedrijfsmiddelen en de partijen waarvan deze afhankelijk zijn, de kernactiviteiten, en de maatschappelijke ‘license to operate’.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. AM Nadolska-den Ouden', 'dr. MG Baaij', 'dr. P Darnihamedani', 'dr. RAJL van Wijk', 'dr. S Liu']
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
​
In today's world competitive advantages erode faster and faster. Globalization, technological development and industry convergence pressure organizations to put more emphasis on corporate strategy. Corporate strategy revolves around the 4 themes of boundaries, diversification, synergy, and innovation. Traditionally, corporate strategy involves the choice in which markets a company is active and managers decided mainly about diversification and resource allocation. These days corporate strategy also concerns leveraging resources across a company’s businesses to create both cost-reducing and value-enhancing synergies and to spur innovation. To get access to relevant resources they do not possess, firms increasingly look beyond their boundaries and seek to acquire and ally with organizations. Such corporate development decisions have become an essential activity of corporate strategy, making corporate development departments central units in many organizations. 

The objective of this course is to help participants develop a conceptual and practical understanding of corporate strategy and the role of corporate development. After successfully completing the course, students will have to their availability a toolkit and skills that help them steer corporate strategy decisions. This includes tools to assess, transform and organize a corporate portfolio of businesses. It also includes tools to make a choice between acquisitions and alliances, and attention will be paid to the implications and managerial challenges alliances and acquisitions pose by addressing the levers of successfully creating value, selecting targets and partners, integrating acquisition targets and controlling alliances. Finally, in addition to accessing new resources through alliances and acquisitions, the shedding of resources through corporate divestments will be addressed. As part of the skills trajectory across the core courses, this course develops two important corporate skills: portfolio analysis and target valuation. Overall, the course develops state-of-the-art understanding of the risks and returns associated with corporate strategy and corporate development, and the managerial skills and capabilities needed to be successful. Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives

After completing the course, the student will have learning the following:
1.    Identify and compare relevant theoretical concepts and frameworks of corporate strategy, corporate development and growth
2.    Integrate theoretical insights and frameworks that shape (1) boundary, (2) diversification, (3) synergy and (4) innovation decisions in corporate development
3.    Apply theoretical insights and frameworks to practical corporate development cases and situations
4.    Collect data and information relevant to corporate development decisions
5.    Analyze opportunities and challenges to develop strategic options for corporate portfolio and ownership decisions
6.    Value target companies in corporate growth situations
7.    Propose a corporate strategy and implementation plan for a company as a corporate strategy team
8.    Demonstrate the ability to work with incomplete information in an ethical way

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['AG Andrei, MSc', 'dr. A Mulder', 'dr. MG Baaij', 'dr. P Darnihamedani', 'dr. S Liu', 'prof.dr. J van Oosterhout']
text:
Inhoud
Contents, course description

This course combines key insights from the areas of Strategic Management and International Business to shed light on the topic of international business strategy. International business strategy means effectively and efficiently matching a multinational firm’s internal strengths (relative to competitors) with the opportunities and challenges found in institutionally and geographically dispersed environments that cross international borders. Such matching is a requirement for creating value and satisfying stakeholders’ goals, both domestically and internationally, and hence for survival and good performance.

Since globalization has increased both the opportunities and challenges found in the international business environment, forming and executing successful international business strategies has become increasingly complex for firms. Developing and building on a unifying framework of the practitioner-oriented literature on international business strategies, this course familiarizes students with the core concepts and dynamics associated with such strategies, thereby increasing students’ academic understanding of successful international strategy formation and implementation.

Format

The main teaching methods used throughout the course are lectures, instructor-led discussions, and team assignments. Students are expected to come prepared to each class by having studied the required readings and being able to explain and defend their team’s answers to the assignment questions. Accordingly, the classes will to a large extent be interactive.


  Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
  • To familiarize students with the key theoretical ideas about international business strategy;
  • To train students in critically evaluating these ideas;
  • To train students in applying these ideas to business practice through real-life case studies of multinational firms;
  • To increase students’ ability to formulate and express their views on the theory and practicalities of international business strategy.
  • To increase students’ ability to understand, develop, and implement successful international business strategies in multinational firms – the overall end goal.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Contents
There is fierce debate over the role of markets and the moral limits to the pursuit of profit by modern corporate enterprise. Is there a corporate responsibility beyond making money? Is the ‘free market’ fair? Are there goods which we should not try to provide via the market such as the adoption of children, human organs, or sexual services? What are these goods, and what is wrong with buying and selling them?
These are the questions addressed in this course which starts from a series of online lectures on political theories of justice, from Aristotle to John Rawls given by Harvard professor of government Michael Sandel. In our class meetings in Rotterdam we will refine this framework and apply it to major questions of markets and justice.
Leerdoelen
Learning objectives
In this course students are introduced to four major normative theories of justice. Students learn to appreciate arguments supporting these positions on the basis of a methodology of normative research. In the class discussions students will learn to apply normative frameworks to questions of justice in the market domain and the business world.

Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud What makes a city creative? In this research workshop, we will answer this question by reviewing and critically assessing theoretical and policy debates that have addressed this question, and by carrying out original empirical research on the topic. Over the past decades, the concept of creative city has encapsulated the anticipation of the economic and social benefits of the arts and the creative industries and their embeddedness in cities, resulting in a number of urban cultural policy interventions. More recently, cities are called upon to be creative in tackling societal challenges, from rising inequalities to the climate crisis. We will start the course by reviewing a number of central writings on creative cities. Students then develop their own original research on an aspect of creative cities, training the qualitative research skills gained in this course. Possible topics for research projects include: exploring clusters of creativity and making in the city; sustainable and inclusive practices in the arts and creative industries; arts, the creative industries and urban gentrification.
  Leerdoelen This course’s aims are threefold: firstly, students become familiarized with and critically reflect upon the key concepts and theories on the nexus between creativity, cultural production and consumption, and cities. Secondly, students train their qualitative research skills, practicing the different stages of research design. Finally, students apply their theoretical and methodological knowledge and research skills to developing and conducting a small qualitative research on the topic of creative cities, presented in oral and written form.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud
<html>
<head>
	<title></title>
	<style type="text/css">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
	</style>
</head>
<body>The economy is changing. Creativity is increasingly seen as a source of competitive advantage and creative assets (such as knowledge, intellectual property, networks, and technology) are increasingly seen as potential generators of economic growth. This course examines this shift in the economy through an organizational lens. Topics include: concepts of creativity; the relationship between creativity and innovation; theories on organizational creativity; distinguishing characteristics of organizations in the creative industries; creative entrepreneurship; how organizations balance the pursuit of creativity against other goals; how managers both foster and (inadvertently) kill creativity; and the nature of creative work, including labor conditions for creative workers.</body>
</html>

Leerdoelen
<html>
<head>
	<title></title>
	<style type="text/css">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
	</style>
</head>
<body>The aim of the course is to develop students' understanding of an economy based on ideas rather than physical goods and the role of organizations in this creative economy. After the course students will be able to explain how the creative or knowledge economy is different from a goods and services based economy, and how the role of organizations changes accordingly. Students will be able to explain how creative organizations are different from other organizations, and how creativity can be fostered within organizations. After the course students will be able to apply these insights in their analysis of creative organizations in a knowledge-based economy. .</body>
</html>

course_title: Creative Industries in the Global Economy
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Cultural and creative industries are increasingly recognized as important generators of revenues and jobs, as well as powerful drivers of cultural globalization, especially as the world moves into the digital age. One 2015 global survey estimated that they created $2.2 trillion in revenue and around 30 million jobs. Yet they are not new phenomenon. The high profile of multinational media companies is often described as dominance and cultural homogenization, yet it disguises the diversity and multipolar nature of the creative industries. Countries and cities have increasingly identified creative industries as an important means of economic development; cultural branding and have increasingly used historical "heritage" as a competitive advantage. We will critically examine the concept of creative industries and the "creative class," how digitalization has made monetization more difficult and altered industry dynamics, and the relationship between cultural industries and development. The course examines why clusters and entrepreneurs emerge at specific points in time (such as Hollywood or Bollywood) and discusses how their competitiveness can be sustained. A special focus will be on how individual firms or clusters in specific places have emerged over time and altered their strategies to redesign themselves for a global digital age. Leerdoelen
·         Students are able to examine critically the concept, history and reality of creative industries.
·         Students understand the particularly dynamics of various creative industries over time, in particular how digitalization is changing these industries.
·         Students can assess and explain how public policy has targeted creative industries as drivers of growth, employment, and development.
·         Students can apply key concepts such as the "gig economy," "precariat," and "creative class," in the analysis of firm-level strategies.
​

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Creativity is one of the most desired aspects of modern work and creativity is seen as central to contemporary work practices. Specifically, jobs in the media and cultural industries are often considered to be the most creative of all. The recent interest in the 'creative industries', as well as the rising number of jobs in these sectors call for renewed attention to the nature of creative work in the media. Creativity requires other working conditions and skills than “regular” work and is often organized differently, with a large number of self-employed entrepreneurs and work that often tends to be project-based.
 
Creative industries’ policies tend to focus on the increase in the number of jobs, based on expanding the conditions for symbolic creativity. For (economic) policy, creativity is objectified as an ‘input’ in order to generate jobs and marketable products – ‘output’. In response, several analysts have pointed to serious problems concerning jobs and professions in these industries, such as uncertainty and 'precariousness'.
 
In this course we will critically assess the specificities of creative labour and the conditions under which it may thrive. We will identify possible drawbacks and benefits to creative employment and we will look at the nature of creative employment, drawing on contemporary work practices. Students will also gain knowledge and understanding of their future areas of employment. Leerdoelen Upon completion of this course, students will have knowledge and understanding of:
  • Current theoretical perspectives on creative labour in the media and cultural industries;
  • Future areas of employment.
                                                                                                    
Students have developed the skills to:
  • Apply relevant theoretical insights in the analysis of creative labour in the media and cultural industries;
  • Critically assess various texts (academic texts, industry reports, policy documents) addressing creative labour;
  • Set up an academic argument on creative labour, both verbally and in writing.
  • Reflect on and make informed choices regarding their future careers.

course_title: Creativity and Innovation in Contemporary Business
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud There is an extensive literature on both creativity and innovation and their relation. The definition of creativity and innovation is overly discussed yet not conclusively. In addition, scholars and practitioners have an ongoing debate on creativity’s relation and influence within human (personal) and business development.
Creativity has its own meaning within education, psychology, business and management, marketing, communications, advertising, arts and entrepreneurship for instance. Depending on which context we take as a framework for creativity, the meaning, the practice and the outcome might differ. The same can be said about when defining what innovation might be. For the same reason, scholars argue for a ‘multidisciplinary definition of innovation’ (Baregheh et al., 2009).
 
To narrow down the comprehensive reach of creativity and innovation within the 21st century’s context, this seminar will focus on creative thinking (CT) & creative problem solving (CPS) theories, methods and applications in more specific. CT and CPS in a 21st century (business) context will benefit students by introducing, understanding and applying essential contemporary knowledge and skills. Besides CT & CPS being a central 21st century personal skill that is required within the work field, it is also a central practice of businesses in coming up with innovative ideas, improvements and thus solutions for product, service and communication/ human related (business) matters/ challenges. 
CT & CPS, both can be related to the ‘creative person’, the creative process, the creative output (products & services) and the creative environment that either facilitates or blocks thus hinders these aspects/ processes. Several (scientific and work) fields can be directly related to these researches and practices. To name a few: Organizational-, business-, product development & communication, organizational and business sustainability, management and leadership-, creativity and innovation studies, communication sciences, (positive) psychology, entrepreneurship, marketing & sales, not to mention people’s career and lives’ in an ever-changing social, societal, economic, political, cultural context. In addition to communication, collaboration is also at the core of CT & CPS processes in a group setting. 
 
Consequently, in this seminar, the focus will be a careful selection of creativity & innovation (CT & CPS) related theories, methods and the practice of those, applicable within several fields of work (and life in general). A solid theoretical backbone will serve for the practical implementation, geared towards a sustainable career development and business operation; product, people and process innovation.

Anahita Baregheh, Jennifer Rowley, Sally Sambrook, (2009) "Towards a multidisciplinary definition of innovation", Management Decision, Vol. 47 Issue: 8, pp.1323-1339, https://doi.org/10.1108/00251740910984578

  Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • Essential theories and methods about creativity & innovation in relation to creative thinking (CT) and creative problem solving (CPS) within a globalized 21st century organizational, team and individual context
  • Realizing the need for contextual awareness to apply creativity and realize innovation (that is ‘out of the box’), feasible and sustainable (for ex.: understanding the importance of the organizational, team and individual context and realizing the implications of historical, political, socio-economic, (multi / inter) cultural, industry or sector/ field related context)
  • Identifying challenges and problems (within an organizational, team and individual setting) and how to differentiate between solvable difficulties to overcome, to transform, and difficulties / situations that need a complete new approach and a solution leaving the ‘old’ behind
  • Knowledge of how to effectively produce and communicate (verbally and in writing) creative & innovative ideas, processes and outcomes (consultancy project)
  • Understanding the need and benefits of a responsive, open, positive attitude and a curious mind-set, allowing out of the box (creative) ideas or (novel) solutions to emerge that fit the ethical framework of the situation / context
  • Understanding the benefits of collaboration and own individual responsibility within a multicultural / intercultural context
 
Students have developed the skills to:
  • To be able to (re)define, elaborate, refine, analyse, and evaluate one’s own ideas to improve and maximize creative (individual and group) efforts within a multicultural setting
  • How to gather (research) and implement methods through which creativity and innovation can be enhanced, fostered, realized and managed within the context of an organization, team, and on an individual level
  • To theorize (research, analyse, write and verbalize) creativity and innovation in a 21st century’s international / multicultural / intercultural business
  • To contextualize theoretical knowledge within an empirical framework. Bringing theory into practice: To create novel solutions to existing and or foreseeable (personal, team and multicultural organizational) challenges
  • To make judgments on why, where, when and how creativity and/or innovation could take place: To implement the presented methods through which creativity and innovation can be enhanced, fostered, realized and managed within the context of an organization, team, and on an individual level
  • To practice critical and analytic skills, while listening, observing, writing, verbalizing the context of multidimensional possibilities within which creativity and innovation can take place
  • Understanding the necessity of a high level of interaction, and when necessary (creatively) enhance collaboration to develop, implement, and communicate new ideas to others effectively within an international framework
  • To develop a deeper level of self-awareness; to be a critical and creative listener, thinker, ‘actor’;
  • To be aware of the need for an open mind-set that fosters every challenge as an opportunity (both within personal and career/ business context)
  • To initiate (besides collaborating) creative ideas to find solutions, approaches and gradually realizing own responsibility in relation to the self and within the context of a group of individuals

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['CE Weeda, MSc', 'dr. GJ Custers, MSc', 'dr. GNG Vanderveen', 'dr. J Jansen, MSc', 'E van der Heijden', 'I Balizi, MSc', 'I Willems', 'jonkvrouw TMA van Suchtelen, MSc', 'M Breijer, MSc', 'MA van Woensel', 'SD Kruit, MSc', 'SMJ Mulder - Leenders']
text:
Inhoud In dit laatste vak van het eerste jaar wordt het Rotterdamse veiligheidsbeleid centraal gesteld. Hoe wordt dit beleid gemaakt, welke veronderstellingen liggen aan het beleid ten grondslag, wat is de rol van de politiek en van criminaliteitscijfers daarbij?  Welk soort maatregelen wordt door de Gemeente getroffen en welke effecten (bedoelde en onbedoelde) hebben deze? Het is de bedoeling dat de student voor het beantwoorden van deze vragen gebruik maakt van de kennis die hij of zij heeft opgedaan bij de eerdere vakken. Daarnaast moet de student zich grondig verdiepen in het beleid. De student stelt zelf een onderzoeksvraag op en beantwoord deze met behulp van desk research. Het vak criminaliteit en samenleving leert de student als het ware om de eigen leefomgeving door een criminologische bril te bekijken Leerdoelen Na het succesvol afronden van dit blok kun je:
 
  1. Betekenissen van definities van concepten als veiligheid in het Rotterdams veiligheidsbeleid identificeren en evalueren;
  2. Veronderstellingen, doelstellingen en (beleids)theorieën herkennen in het Rotterdamse veiligheidsbeleid en deze kritisch beoordelen op basis van wetenschappelijke juridische en empirische literatuur;
  3. Kwantitatieve en kwalitatieve databronnen in het Rotterdams veiligheidsbeleid herkennen en beoordelen;
  4. Een onderzoeksvraag opstellen gerelateerd aan het Rotterdamse veiligheidsbeleid die te beantwoorden is met bronnenonderzoek (desk research), dit onderzoek uitvoeren en hierover rapporteren;
  5. Een gestructureerde, samenhangende en kritische analyse schrijven over het Rotterdams veiligheidsbeleid.

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['CE Weeda, MSc', 'dr. A Bouabid', 'dr. W van der Wagen, MSc', 'drs. CCF van Guldener', 'drs. SL van den Kieboom', 'JC Willink, MSc', 'M Moussane, MSc']
text:
Inhoud In dit vak staan daders en hun criminele carrières centraal.  Na het volgen van dit vak is de student in staat om verschillende soorten criminele carrières te beschrijven en te verklaren aan de hand van verschillende criminologische theoretische perspectieven. Daarbij worden de criminele carrières ook bekeken vanuit het perspectief van de daders zelf, en zullen de verschillende relaties tussen werk en criminaliteit worden bestudeerd. In de hoorcolleges wordt dieper ingegaan op de stof, en zullen meerdere gastdocenten verhalen over de loopbanen van criminelen. Ook zal er een college worden gegeven door iemand die vertelt over zijn eigen criminele carrière. Tijdens het practicum zullen de studenten de carrières van echte criminelen bestuderen, en verschillende concepten uit de literatuur daarop leren toepassen Leerdoelen Na het volgen van dit blok kun je:
 
  1. Het ontstaan, de ontwikkeling en de beëindiging van verschillende criminele carrières beschrijven en verklaren. 
  2. Centrale criminologische concepten die samenhangen met het ontstaan, de ontwikkeling en de beëindiging van criminele carrières benoemen en toepassen op verschillende criminele carrières. 
  3. Het ontstaan, de ontwikkeling en de beëindiging van verschillende criminele carrières vergelijken op hun belangrijkste kenmerken, vragen en verklaringen. 
  4. De mogelijkheden en beperkingen uitleggen en duiden van verschillende theoretische en methodologische perspectieven op criminele carrières.

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['AKG Thelen, MSc', 'dr. TFC Fischer', 'dr.mr. F Geelhoed', 'drs. EG Brein, MSc', 'drs. VD van Santvoord', 'F. Geelhoed', 'prof.dr. CG van Wingerde', 'prof.dr. RHJM Staring']
text: Inhoud Leerdoelen This course aims to develop in students critical analysis, problem solving and research skills in the field of research on criminal justice policies, which will allow students both to be critical consumers of research, and to develop research in this field in practice. First, this course contributes to a better understanding of the key types of evaluation research, the methodological and practical issues involved and it discusses practical solutions for conducting evaluation research in practice. Secondly, students will learn the techniques of risk assessments and qualitative data-analysis and they will learn to critically reflect on those techniques. Thirdly, students will develop an understanding of the ethical dilemma’s involved in conducting criminological research for public policy making. Lastly, it contributes to a better understanding of the ways in which research findings can be transferred into policy making and to an understanding of the limits thereof.

course_title: Criminology: a broadening minor. The twilight zone between legal and illegal.
college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['dr. G van Eijk', 'dr. JW Hiah', 'jonkvrouw TMA van Suchtelen, MSc', 'prof.dr. LCJ Bisschop', 'RI Timmerman, MA']
text:
Inhoud At first sight, crime might seem like an easy concept to grasp, especially when this refers to murder, rape or robbery. However, there are many other phenomena such as corporate malfeasance or drug use that are on a thin line between the legal and the illegal. Some might be criminalized, whereas others might be harmful yet not part of criminal law or other regulations. Discussions about the meaning of crime as well as the social constructivist character of crime are key to any criminology programme. Criminology also sheds light on possible causes as well as consequences of crime for society. This implies that criminology deals with a diversity of possible causes, offenders as well as victims, and also keeps an open mind about the most suitable approach to deal with crime, ranging from criminal law to prevention policy. Criminology is an inherently multidisciplinary social science and bridges insights from sociology, (socio-) legal studies, anthropology, psychology and public management. This is reflected on theoretical, methodological as well as empirical level. Contemporary developments in criminology and in criminal justice and social policies will run as a thread through this minor. Given that much of the developments in contemporary crime are inherently global, we also pay attention to these elements of globalization in view of criminalization, aetiology and approaches to crime, while at the same time not losing track of local particularities of crime. Think for instance of topics such as drug trafficking, human smuggling and (irregular) migration, dumping of waste, cybercrime, terrorism, etc. This minor also takes a critical approach to the study of crime. We deem it essential for criminologists to approach crime phenomena and crime policies with a critical, multidisciplinary and comparative gaze.

This criminology minor is a broadening (1) minor. It is impossible to touch upon all the dynamics of criminology within this minor, but students will be introduced to the core concepts, theories and methods of criminology, to the basics of crime control and prevention and to contemporary developments in the field of crime and justice. Combined with sufficient methodological knowledge, this criminology minor prepares for a successful participation in the regular EUR master Criminology with its focus on crime and the city, globalization, multiculturalism and organizational crime.
 
1. I.e. it is not open to bachelor students in criminology.

For more information visit minoren esl
Leerdoelen By the end of this minor, students will be able to:
  1. Explain the key concepts in criminology
  2. Differentiate between different definitions of crime and assess their implications for policy making
  3. Name and explain the most important criminological research methods and assess their strengths and weaknesses
  4. Understand the importance of criminological research for criminal justice and social policy
  5. Compare different theoretical approaches to crime in terms of research questions, hypotheses and levels of analysis
  6. Discuss the strengths and weaknesses of criminological theories based on research findings
  7. Apply the key criminological theories to specific criminological phenomena and current issues
  8. Describe the objectives of different approaches to crime
  9. Discuss questions of effectiveness and justice of different approaches to crime
  10. Describe recent developments in the field of criminology
